He has many customers because he has worked this route for a long time so he knows the people who live nearby very well. What he likes most about his job is the freedom it gives him for he can peacefully drive his minibus through the streets looking for customers. He has been doing this for 10 years and feels that the most difficult side of the job is having to repair his vehicle when something goes wrong. For the future, he would like to have a more profitable business, perhaps a car repair shop. This is Lenin's fifth loan with MFP. He knows he has to repay on time because he doesn't want to cause any problems for the other members of the communal bank where he is one of the few male members so he feels particularly obliged to be responsible. With the 1,000 soles requested he will repair his vehicle's motor which, with the passing of time, has deteriorated.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For engine repairs.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.es:
Nilda tiene 22 años, es soltera, vive en su casa propia, y lo que más desea es forjarse una buena vida.
Su carisma es una de sus armas más importantes a la hora de desempeñar su labor, ella es la encargada de cobrar los pasajes en la combi número 12 que brinda servicio de transporte urbano por las calles de Juliaca. Su día comienza muy temprano por la mañana, teniendo que permanecer en su labor hasta casi las 9 de la noche.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que puede conversar con sus pasajeros y hacer más ameno el viaje, lleva 2 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día parada, ya que los pasajeros ocupan todos los asientos. 
Para más adelante, anhela tener su propia combi, con la cual pueda trabajar y obtener sus propias ganancias.

Este es el cuarto préstamo de Nilda con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a su banco comunal, donde es una socia muy querida y admirada. Con los dos mil soles solicitados planea apoyar en los arreglos de la combi donde trabaja, ya que si se malogra, ella no tendrá trabajo.
texts.en:
Nilda, 22, is single and lives in her own home; her greatest wish is to build a good life for herself. Her charisma is one of her most powerful weapons in her work since she is the person charged with collecting fares onboard minibus #12 which provides urban public transportation services on the streets of Juliaca. Her workday begins very early in the morning and doesn't end until almost 9 at night. What she most enjoys about the job is being able to converse with the passengers and make the trip more pleasant. She has had this job for two years and feels that the most difficult part of it is having to stand all day since the passengers take up all the available seats. For later in the future she would like to own her own minibus with which to work and earn her own profits. This is Nilda's fourth loan with MFP. She is aware that she needs to repay in a timely fashion and is prepared to do so since she does not want to cause any problems for her communal bank where she is a well-liked and admired member. With the 2,000 soles requested she plans to help defray repay costs for the minibus that she works on because if it breaks down she won't have a job.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Minibus repair.

loans.name: Seferina

texts.en:
Seferina U. is engaged in a retail rice business in her village. She also sells fruits and vegetables whenever she has sufficient capital to purchase them for resale.

She would like to borrow 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from the Kiva lenders. The loan will be used to purchase additional items to sell, like fruits, vegetables, and rice.

With the loan, she believes that she can expand her business and, in this way, further provide for the needs of her family. She hopes that the Kiva lenders will entrust her with a loan to make her business grow.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Richar

texts.es:
Richar, de 21 años es un joven muy responsable y trabajador, vive en una habitación alquilada, él tiene muchas ganas de sobresalir en la vida y mejorar su futuro.

Sus días comienzan muy temprano, aproximadamente a las 4 de la mañana sale con su combi (camioneta) a ganarse la vida llevando pasajeros hasta sus destinos. Junto a su inseparable cobrador, recorren las calles de la ciudad de Juliaca, siguiendo la ruta número 12 para llegar a su destino.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es recorrer las calles de la ciudad y distraerse, le gusta tanto conducir, que apenas cumplió la mayoría de edad, decidió ponerse a trabajar en una empresa de transportes. Lleva 3 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es permanecer todos los días sentado en su combi dejando de lado las cosas que desearía hacer. 
Con el paso del tiempo, anhela tener su propia combi y administrarla él mismo.

Este es el tercer préstamo de Richar con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesto a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es muy responsable, ya que no quiere quedar mal ante el resto de sus compañeras. Los dos mil soles solicitados los invertirá en la recategorización de su licencia de conducir, el resto del dinero lo invertirá en el arreglo de la combi en la que trabaja, para así brindarle un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Richar, 21, is a responsible, hard-working young man. He lives in a rented room and very much wants to get ahead in life and improve his future. His workday starts very early, around 4am, when he goes out to earn his daily wage transporting passengers to their destinations in his minibus. Together with his inseparable fare collector they travel the streets of Juliaca, following route #12, to reach their destination. What he most likes about the job is to amuse himself traveling through the streets. He enjoys driving so much that he decided to be a driver for a transportation company as soon as he became of age. He has had this job for three years and considers the hardest part of the job is to be sitting in his minubus all day and not being able to do all the other things he'd like to do. With time, he'd like to own and administer his own minibus. This is Richar's third loan with MFP and he knows that he must repay on time and is prepared to do so. He is considered very responsible in his communal bank and he does not want to let the other members down. The 2,000 soles requested will be used to change his driver's license classification. The rest of the money will be used for minibus repairs so that better service can be offered his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To change the classification of his driver's license.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is 52 years old and married to Gauvencio, a bus operator for Dagupan Bus. They have six children; three of them are already married and three are still studying. The couple and their three children are living in Sitio Guingab, Tumauini, Isabela. They hope and dream that their children will finish their college education.

Milagros is engaged in selling firewood in their village with the help of her husband. Their business is in demand in their village, since most of the residents use firewood especially in cooking because it is cheaper compared to gas. Some of the her income from selling firewood is being used as capital in retailing soap.

At present, she is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 to be used in purchasing more firewood to have an increase in income. Aside from this, she is also planning to expand her soap retailing business for additional income. She hopes that her dreams for this business will be achieved so she can continue to meet the needs of their family, especially the education of their children.

loans.use: Additonal capital to buy wood to cut into firewood

loans.name: Geronima T.

texts.en:
Geronima T. R. is from the village of Lupagan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 71 years old. Geronima T. is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Geronima T. owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Geronima T. is just starting this business.

In 2008, Geronima T. joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Geronima T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from PMPC. Geronima T. is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to finish the fence at their house. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Geronima T. from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to finish the fence at their house

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem P., 41, is a married woman and the mother of four children. Three of them are married and the other is a pupil and dependent on her income. To earn a living, Nhem P. always buys a various flowers in bulk from growers to sell retail along the streets around the community. To help be responsible for supporting the family, her husband owns a small vehicle repair business; he is shown in the picture.

Nhem P. has been using her old motorbike for her business for many years, so it is too old and often breaks down and affects her income. Nhem P. is therefore requesting a loan of US$ 700 which she will use to replace her existing motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace her existing motorcycle

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora is 53 years old and a resident of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. She is married and gifted with two children who are both studying. She hopes that through her business and her husband’s source of income, they will be able to provide all the needs of their children, especially when it comes to their education.

Aurora is a hog raiser. She wants her hogs to grow healthy so she can sell them at higher prices. Another source of income Aurora manages is her vending business. She sells vegetables in their village and generates a profit of PHP 2,000 a month. This is a good business for her because it is where her family gets their daily expenses. She always hopes to further expand her business to provide sufficient support for her family.

She is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000. This amount will assist her in providing the hogs with enough feed for their growth and also be used for her vegetable vending business.

loans.use: feed for her hogs and capital for her vegetable vending business

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia A. is from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Alicia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Alicia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Alicia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng S. M., 25, is a young woman and the mother of a school-aged child. To earn a living, Leng S. M. owns a small store where there is the good location to raise income. In her shop, she sells different kinds of flowers to people who need to decorate for parties or ceremonies. In her business activities, her husband also assists her in buying and selling flowers. This family normally earns an average of $7 per day to help cover their family’s daily living expenses.

Leng S. M. currently is selling well because she has a skill in public communication with people. To meet the needs of her family, she is applying for a loan which she will use as capital to accumulate a quantity of various flowers to sell.

loans.use: To buy flowers to sell

loans.name: Chhai

texts.en:
Mr. Chhai P. is 40 years of age and a married man. He is a local farmer and is also hired by neighbor to cook meals for their parties or ceremonies. He normally makes around US$ 5 in income each day to support his family. His wife stays at home to care for three teenaged children and does housework and also works on the farm.

Chhai P. grows his rice crop over months and he has to deal with the fact that his field is far from the water system. Therefore, Chhai P. would like to ask for a loan of US$ 1000 in order to buy a pump for irrigation. He proposes to use the rest of his loan to purchase a used motorbike for a traveling. Chhai P. was busy at his farm so his wife is shown instead.

loans.use: To buy a pump for irrigation

loans.name: Sod

texts.en:
Sod L., 30, is married with three school-aged children. She resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in the agriculture sector, raising pigs, earning an income of US$ 3 per day. The family is assisted mainly by her husband who is a construction builder in the city, earning collectively an income of US$ 7 per day as a primary source of income for the family to help cover the household expenses.

Mrs. L. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. Therefore, L. is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase more pigs and piglets to raise to expand her agricultural business. She hopes that she will be able to generate more income with her proper business plan enabled by her expected loan.

loans.use: buy more pigs and piglets to raise

loans.name: Phum

texts.en:
Phum C. was born in 1968 and has established a small family in the best territory of Phnom Penh, the city of Cambodia. In order to generate profit, Phum C. sells flowers that she grows on her own land in the village. Her husband also goes to buy bananas in bulk to resell to earn a living and typically earns US$ 5 a day.

Phum C. and her husband have been married for many years and have four children. One of them is newly married and starting new home, while other three are working or studying. Due to the fact that flowers command the highest prices, Phum C. hopes to grow lots more flowers for sale. She would therefore like a loan to buy seeds for growing flowers.

loans.use: To buy seeds for growing flowers

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao L., 29, resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with his wife and three children. To make a living, he operates his motorbike as a taxi  everywhere in the town, earning an income of US $3 per day, while his wife sells sugar cane juice, bringing total family income to US $5 per day, which covers the basic household expenses. Mao and his family are seeking to improve their standard of living, and so he is requesting a loan of US $1000 to replace his old motorbike, which is in need of frequent repairs, with a new one to improve his current business.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Roselle

texts.en: Roselle L., 28 years old, is engaged in the motorcycle business with her husband, Roberto, serving as the driver. As well, he manages their small farm lot where they grow rice. The couple has been blessed with two children, Robert, eight years old and Michael Eiron, seven years old.  Roselle would like to improve their standard of  living by improving their businesses and so is requesting a loan of Php 9,000 for the maintenance of her tricycle and support of their rice farm.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of motorcycle and rice farm

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is engaged in the hair-cutting and hairdressing business. For nine years, this has been her main source of income which really helps in providing for the daily needs of their family. Clarita is now requesting a loan of PHP6,000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance and improvement of her business.

Clarita is 57 years old, married and living in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. A previous loan was used to purchase additional hogs for her hog-raising business. She converted from a poultry to a livestock operation because she believes that she will earn more income from it. She hopes that with the continuing support of Kiva lenders, their way of living will improve.

loans.use: Additional capital to maintain and improve her her business

loans.name: Kulazia's Group

texts.en:
Kulazia is forty eight years old and is the leader of this group. She is a leading specialist in a social fund. Her husband works as a driver for a company. Kulazia and her husband have raised three children. The eldest and the middle sons, 28 and 26 respectively, have taken after their father and work as drivers. The little daughter, 24, is a saleswoman. She is also getting distant education at university. In modern times it has become quite disadvantageous to restrict oneself to have only one occupation. Kulazia is fortunate as fifteen years ago her little brother gave her eldest son a milk cow as a present. Kulazia started to look after the cow even though she was working at that time. Her little brother, having experience in raising livestock, showed them how to look after the cow since neither Kulazia nor her husband has ever looked after cattle before. Even now, her little brother still helps Kulazia look after the cattle. The fact is that, during these years, Kulazia has managed to increase their total cattle population. From time to time she would sell some of her cattle to make repairs to her house and to buy some convenience goods. At this time, Kulazia hopes that she will be able to obtain this loan to buy one more milk cow to sell more milk and increase their cow population. One of her projects for the near future is to start building a big house. The following people are Kulazia’s partners: Anarkul, 46, works in a social fund. She needs a loan to buy a calf. According to her, cattle are a good asset to help her children get on their feet. Bubusaira, 60, is a widow and is the mother of three children. She needs a loan to buy a calf. Azamat, 29, is married and has a two-year-old son. He works as a taxi-driver and needs a loan to purchase tires. Surakan, 47, is a widow. She works and raises cattle. She needs a loan to buy a calf. Kulchoro, 41, trades in various goods. He needs a loan to purchase office supplies to expand his assortment. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow to sell more milk and increase the size of her herd

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 33 years old and a very assiduous businesswoman. She is married to Joselito, who is engaged in the trucking business. They have two children: Crisanto, a first year high school student, and Joan, a grade five student. Their family lives happily and peacefully in the village of Sitio Guingab, Tumauini, Isabela.

Merlita has been engaged in the poultry business for years. Aside from this, she is also engaged in a soap-vending business that she purchased in Bulacan. From these businesses, the income she generates is just enough to meet the daily needs of their family.

Merlita would like to borrow PHP 6,000 from Kiva lenders. She will use the loan to purchase additional chicks to raise and also soap to increase her income. The loan will benefit a lot, not only her business but also their family.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and soap

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline O. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Evangeline owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Evangeline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Together with her husband, Veronica owns and operates a furniture-making business. She is now asking to borrow PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders that she needs to buy more wood for making different kinds of furniture. She is hoping that her loan will be approved so that she can meet the demands of her customers and also have an increase in income.

Veronica and her husband are blessed with eight children. She and her family lives in the village of San Isidro, Ilagan, Isabela. Veronica dreams of improving their business in order to have a more comfortable way of living.

loans.use: To buy more wood for her furniture-making business

loans.name: Lea

texts.en: Lea O. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 23 years old and is single. Lea owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Farming is the main source of income of Julita and her family. The couple are blessed with two children and both of them are already married.

To earn additional income Julita also ventured into the vending of cosmetic products within her village of Rizal, Santiago City. According to Julita, she would like to improve their way of living through her vending business. She would like to borrow additional capital of Php 8,000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of her rice farming and vending activities.

Julita hopes that she will be able to obtain the amount she is requesting so that she can generate a bigger income. This amount will serve as a big help to her, most especially in their daily needs in life.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her rice farming and vending activities

loans.name: Nonina

texts.en:
Nonina is 44 years old and serves as the father and mother to her two children: John Lexter - 19 years old, and Anjanette - 17 years old, both in college.

Nonina manages a sari-sari store business (community based store) in her village of Rizal, Santiago City. Aside from her retailing business, she also manages their fishpond.

Nonina would like to improve her fish pond and buy additional groceries for her store. Therefore, she is now asking to borrow PHP 10,000 to pursue her business plans. This amount could really help her, most especially in providing for the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her store and to improve her fishpond

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is a 30-year-old businesswoman and is already married. They have one child who is presently studying. She and her husband are working hard to be able to provide for the growing needs of their family and their child.

Janeth has been a direct dealer of MSE, Natasha, Sundance and BoardWalk products for three years. Her need for financial assistance encouraged her to borrow a loan of PHP 7,0000 from Kiva lenders. She will use the loan as additional capital in purchasing different products from MSE, Natasha, Sundance and BoardWalk. In this way, she will be able to sell her products more easily than with brochures only.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her direct-selling business

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en: Mrs. Kunthea T. is a villager in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She has four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study because this child is only three months old.  Mrs T. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. On this plantation she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the field and to make the field more productive. Thus, Mrs. Kunthea T. has decided to ask for a loan for that purpose. She would use the rest of the loan to buy a pig and pig food for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Nob No, helps her in the business activities.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the field to make it more productive.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna R. is from the village of Pines Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old. Myrna is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Myrna owns and runs a "sari-sari" (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling various different products, such as shampoo, toothpaste, sugar, milo, sweet candies, et cetera, to the community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Myrna joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Currently, Myrna is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use the additional capital to expand her business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Myrna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and further expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: expanding her business

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn O. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 31 years old. Emelyn is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Emelyn owns and runs a "sari-sari" (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products to the community. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Emelyn joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelyn is currently requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP; the money will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Emelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing additional products to sell

loans.name: Dinar's Group

texts.ru:
Динар живёт в г. Карабалта. Она лидер этой группы. Динар в разводе и у неё трое детей. К счастью двое сыновей уже подросли и сами зарабатывают себе на жизнь. Старшему сыну двадцать один год. Он работает в г. Бишкек. Второму сыну двадцать лет. Он выучился на сварщика и работает по профессии. Младшей дочери пятнадцать лет. Она учится в средней школе. Свои сорок пять лет Динар успешно занимается животноводством. Она копила средства и когда накопила достаточную сумму ,при первой же возможности купила двух телят. Это сравнительно недавнее её занятие. Так как этим делом она занимается всего последние пять лет. Не смотря на то, что животноводство не вполне женское дело Динар довольно быстро приобщилась к нему, и ей удалось заметно улучшить свой жизненный уровень. Её месячный доход составляет около тысячи сом. Чтобы удовлетворять повседневные нужды, Динар продаёт молоко, а когда ей нужна большая сумма денег, она всегда может продать кое-что из своей живности. Оба сыновей и дочка всегда помогают своей матери по мере возможности. Поэтому Динар не испытывает больших трудностей в уходе за скотом. Сейчас Динар нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить тёлку. Она хочет откормить и перепродать е	ё. Динар вовсе не собирается уходить на постоянный отдых. Она хочет максимально помочь своим сыновьям жениться и дать высшее образование дочери. 
 Динар имеет три партнёра по группе: 
Гульмире пятьдесят один год. Её муж работает на стройке. Сама Гульмира предоставляет услуги массажиста. У них трое детей. Двое уже работают, а младшая дочь учится в университете. Гульмира обратилась за кредитом с целью купить дойную корову. Она планирует дома открыть комнату массажиста, научить младшую дочь делать массаж.
Майрамкуль пятьдесят лет. Она мать пятерых детей. Старшей дочери тридцать, а младшей всего одиннадцать. Майрамкуль занимается розничной торговлей продовольственных товаров в собственном киоске. Майрамкуль надеется получить кредит и вложить средства в бизнес для увеличения товарооборота, а на оставшуюся часть средств закупить уголь на зиму.
Качкын пятьдесят три года. Она мать четверых детей. Муж Качкын работает на стройке. Сама же разводит скот и занимается перепродажей. Качкын нужен кредит для того, чтобы купить телёнка. У Качкын много планов. В ближайшем будущем она собирается приобрести мебель, автомашину, женить сына и отремонтировать сарай.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Dinar lives in Kara-Balta. She is the leader of this group. Dinar is divorced and has three children. Fortunately, her two sons have already grown up and work for a living themselves. Her eldest son is twenty-one years old. He works in Bishkek. Her second son is twenty. He studied to be a welder and now works in the trade. Her youngest daughter is fifteen years old and studies in high school. The forty-five year old Dinar has a successful animal husbandry business. She put aside capital and, when she had saved enough, purchased two calves at the first opportunity. Her business started relatively recently. She has been running the business for the last five years. In spite of the fact that animal husbandry is not traditionally thought of as women’s work, Dinar has quickly become familiar with the business and has been able to noticeably improve her standard of living. Her monthly income is around a thousand som. To meet her daily needs, Dinar sells milk and when she needs a large sum of money, she always can sell one of her animals. Both of her sons and her daughter always help their mother to the best of their ability.Therefore, Dinar is not experiencing large difficulties with managing her livestock. Now Dinar needs a loan to purchase a calf to rear and resell. Dinar isn't planning to go away on a permanent vacation. She wants to help her son get married and her daughter go to college.

Dinar has three partners in her group:

Gulmira is fifty one years old. Her husband works in construction. Gulmira herself provides massage services. She and her husband have three children. Two are already working and the youngest daughter studies at college. Gulmira is asking for credit in order to purchase a dairy cow. She plans to open a massage room in her home and to teach her youngest daughter how to give massages.

Mairamkul is fifty years old and a mother of five. Her eldest daughter is thirty and the youngest is only eleven. Mairamkul works in retail and sells groceries in her own kiosk. Mairamkul hopes to receive a loan and invest the capital in the business to increase turnover and use the remaining funds to purchase coal for the winter.

Kachkyn is fifty three years old and a mother of four. Kachkyn's husband works in construction. She herself raises cattle and resells them. Kachkyn needs a loan to purchase a calf. Kachkyn has many plans. In the near future, she plans to acquire furniture, a car, fund her son's wedding and repair her barn.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Amanda Ross, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy, rear and then resell a calf to finance son's wedding and daughter's education

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Yoeun S. is a villager in Ta Pov village in Takeo province. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school and the other is a laborer. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Ouch Sokha, is a bicycle repairer. Since this business is going well, he wants to buy more bicycle parts to use in his repair business. Thus, Mrs. Yoeun S. decided to ask for a loan for her husband's business and she would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer, and pesticides to support the rice field and make it more productive.

loans.use: To buy more bicycle parts and to buy fertilizer, and pesticides.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan B. is a villager in Khnar Thum village in Takeo province. She is a weaver and she wants to expand her business by purchasing more raw materials. She hopes to increase income and improve the family living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Chheang Mao, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Phan B. is a mother of four children one of whom is a silk weaver while two others are employed in a garment factory and the youngest one is enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet sells eggs, frozen foods and smoked fish in her village. She has been doing this for about a year. Her business is very helpful in providing for her family and helping her children continue their schooling. She is currently asking to borrow PHP 6,000; she will use this money to expand her business. More specifically, she will budget the loan to buy additional commodities to sell.  

Juliet is married and resides with her family in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. She sends her three children to school and she is glad that her business is there to support their needs.

loans.use: purchasing more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Clarissa

texts.en:
Clarissa A. is 44 years old and is from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. She lives with her husband Wilfredo and their four children.

Clarissa owns a general store located at their house. She also maintains computer game consoles, which she rents out to gamers. Lastly, she sells electronic credits for mobile phones. Between these three activities, she earns approximately P 3,000.00 a month (except for the rainy season, during which she earns a little less).

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 and has since been enjoying the many benefits it provides to its members. Clarissa has just finished repaying her previous loan with CCT and has applied for a new loan amounting to P 8,000.00.  She needs this money so that she can purchase more products for her store.  

Ultimately, Clarissa hopes to run a large grocery store in her community.      

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchasing more grocery products for her store

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en: Mrs. Sambath T. is a villager in Angk Roneab village in Takeo. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice for earning a living. Aside from this, she is also a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding and food for them. She hopes to increase her income and improve her business. Her husband, Mr. Ngaet Sun, helps her with her business. Mrs. Sambath T. has one child who is a laborer. Her husband is shown at the left in the photo.

loans.use: to buy more piglets or breeding and food for them.

loans.name: Mary Nyokabi

texts.en:
Mary Nyokabi is 31 years old and is married with one son. She owns a boutique where she sells new clothes to her clients, who are from Wangige. She also gets orders for wedding attire. She has been running this business for the past four years and has been able to get a profit of about 25,000 Kenya Shillings a month.  

She has never borrowed from another MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. She wants to use the loan for which she has applied to purchase more clothes in preparation for the December festivities, when demand increases dramatically. 

One day, she hopes to have a big boutique and open other outlets in other places, especialy in the City of Nairobi.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: purchasing more clothing to sell to customers in preparation for the December festivities

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom C. is a villager in Ta Koem village in Takeo province. She is also a pig breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing four more piglets and pig food for them. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family living with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Ton Phanna, is a motorbike taxi driver who also makes a small income to support the family. Mrs. Mom C. is a mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy four more piglets and pig food.

loans.name: Dinara's Group

texts.en:
Dinara is the leader of this group. She is divorced and has a daughter, 21, who is a college student. About four years ago, Dinara decided to become engaged in commerce. She had been saving money prior to her decision and, after saving some amount of money, Dinara invested it in purchasing goods. Now, she trades in foodstuffs and owns a small shop by her house. During these years, Dinara’s trade has allowed her to live a decent life and even make a repair to her house. Her monthly income constitutes around $140. Now, her occupation lets her meet her daily needs. However, Dinara, aside from supporting her family, also has to pay for her daughter’s education. The amount of the tuition fees requires Dinara to give at once quite a large sum of money, which she cannot do at the present time. Therefore, Dinara saw that the only decision was to apply for this loan. She hopes that this loan will enable her to save time and pay the tuition fee at once. Then her small business would allow her to gradually save money to pay it back. Dinara has many plans for the future. Now, her only care is to give her sole daughter a good education. Then she is going to see her married. After fulfilling her parental responsibilities she is going to invest all her efforts in opening a bigger shop next to her house. Dinara has three partners: Elmira, 43, is currently unemployed. Her husband works as a tractor driver. Elmira has raised five children and the little child is just three years old. Elmira has applied for this loan to buy a calf to raise. Mairamkul, 50, is a widow and is occupied with animal husbandry. She has two sons and the eldest son helps her to look after the cattle. She needs a loan to buy a milk cow. An extra cow would allow her to sell more milk and increase her earnings. Dilarom, 22, is divorced. She is sole supporter of her family which consists of her mother and sister. Dilarom works as a schoolteacher and needs a loan to buy a calf. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's education

loans.name: Simplicia

texts.en:
Simplicia is 49 years old and a business woman. She is married and blessed with six children; some are studying and some are already married. Their family lives on Luzon in the village of San Isidro, a part of Ilagan municipality in Isabela province. Together with her loving husband, Simplicia makes furniture. Making different types of furniture has been their main source of income for fifteen years.

Simplicia is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP from Kiva lenders through Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. (ASKI) to purchase more wood. She hopes that her loan request will be granted, for it will benefit her family and her business.

loans.use: To purchase wood for her furniture-making business.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia Z. is from the village of Luz Banson, a barangay in Jasaan municipality located in Misamis Oriental province on Mindanao Island. She is 45 years old, married and has four school-aged children. Lydia owns a shop from which she sells generic drugs to the local community. Lydia has been in business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In May 2009, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, her third from HSPFI, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell (she has repaid her second loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI). She plans to use all additional revenue to pay for her children’s education.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie O. is from the municipality of Manticao in Misamis Oriental province on the island of Mindanao. She is 41 years old, married and has five school-aged children. Tessie’s main source of income comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, to the local community. Tessie has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Tessie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, her first from HSPFI, to be used to buy more seafood products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional seafood products to sell.

loans.name: Annaliza

texts.en: Annaliza M. is a 30-year-old store owner from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. She lives with her three children of whom two are in grade school and the youngest stays at home. Her husband, Reymar, 29, is a shoemaker. Annaliza manages her own general store which she started very small with only a handful of items to sell. Now, her store is one of the prominent ones in their area. She already makes a monthly income of up to P16,000. Annaliza is now on her 4th loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She has applied for a new loan of P10,000 to buy more items to sell in her store. Annaliza wants to see her general store in the future to be bigger than what it is now so that she can help employ some of her neighbors. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Savet

texts.en: Mrs. Savet Y. is a villager in Slaeng Kaong village in Takeo province. She is a grocer and now she wants to expand her store. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more grocery products to resell in order to earn more profits. She hopes to improve her business and provide a better life for her children. Mrs. Savet Y. is a widow with one child who is attending the local school.

loans.use: to buy more grocery products to resell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lek

texts.en:
Lek S., 35 years old, is a humble villager living in the capital, Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. She is married and blessed with a young school-aged child, while her husband is a motorbike taxi driver.

To earn a living, Lek S. sells many kinds of flowers which she either buys in bulk from her supplier or grows them. Her husband always picks up the flowers for her before he starts providing his taxi service.

Unfortunately, an existing motorbike often has broken down during use. Because of that, Lek S. has decided to seek a loan of $500 from Kiva, which she will use to change the broken motorcycle.

loans.use: To change her husband's broken motorcycle

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie B. is married to Romeo B., who works as a carpenter. They are blessed with four children and they are happily residing in Culalabat, Cauayan City, Isabela. Rosemarie has been engaged in the hog raising business for three months. Her net profit every time she disposes of one hog is Php3,000. Recognizing the potential for success of the business, Rosemarie is requesting a loan of Php6,000 from KIVA lenders for her to continue to manage it. This is her 3rd loan cycle. She plans to use the loan to buy  feed and for the improvement of her pig pens.To gain more income for her family, Rosemarie also provides laundry services for her neighbors to have an alternative source of income.

loans.use: To buy hog feed and materials for the improvement of pig pens

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en: Mrs. Sareth H. is a villager in Sman Pream village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice in order to make a living. Her husband, Mr. Dath Sokheng, is a vegetable seller. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for selling vegetables door to door. Mrs. Sareth H. is the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because this child is only one year old. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for selling vegetables door to door.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria B. is from the village of Resthouse, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 43 years old. Victoria is married and has 5 school-age children. To make a living, Victoria owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Victoria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Victoria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Isam

texts.en:
Isam is a 33-year-old married man who owns and operates a small auto repair shop in Nablus city, Palestine. He and his wife have two children.
Isam is a hard-working and very responsible person. The clients value his skills as well as his honesty. Thus, he has many repeat clients. He works hard to earn a good income and support his family. Now he needs a loan of $3000 to buy the necessary tools for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy the necessary tools for improving his business

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Mrs. Pheng P. is a villager in Ta Koem village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 0.7-hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Chea Yuth, is a construction worker. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Pheng P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This couple has one child who is attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.ru:
Осмоналиева Гульнара – лидер данной группы. Ей сорок три года. В такое время, когда кругом безработица, и люди порой оказываются в затруднительном положении из – за незнания, чем заняться, пример Осмоналиевой Гульнары довольно вдохновляющий. Она не стала, как многие другие люди искать работу или сидеть и жаловаться на своё положение. Она вместе с мужем быстро сообразила, что сейчас время, когда люди должны сами себе создавать рабочие места и тихо дело, которым было бы и удобно заниматься и которое не требовало бы больших вложений. К тому же, помогли родители, у которых и опыту было больше и средств, чтобы поддержать начинания детей. И вот Гульнара и её муж уже пятнадцать лет занимаются животноводством. Её муж очень всю жизнь проработал пастухом. Сейчас он пасёт скот, a Гульнара занимается перепродажей скота. Они откармливают и продают овец. Этим занимались ещё их родители, которые и посоветовали им заняться разведением скота. Гульнара вырастила троих детей. Старшая дочь уже замужем. Ей двадцать три года. Среднему сыну двадцать два года. Он работает в г. Бишкек на стройке. Младшей дочери пятнадцать лет. Она учится в школе. Занимаясь разведением скота Гульнара и её муж, смогли купить дом, а также выдать дочь замуж. Сейчас их ежемесячный доход составляет около двух тысяч сомов. Это очень маленький доход. Однако имеющаяся живность позволяет Гульнаре смелее смотреть на завтрашний день. Сейчас Гульнара намеревается купить ещё одну корову для содержания. Она очень надеется, что данный кредит позволит ей осуществить задуманное.
Партнёры Гульнары по группе:
Бакиру сорок три года. Бакир тринадцать лет занимается животноводством, а жена сидит дома и торгует штучными товарами. У них трое детей. Все дети ходят в школу a после школы помогают отцу по хозяйству. Бакир хочет получить кредит и купить телёнка для откорма и продажи. 
Гульсун сорок семь лет. У неё единственный сын. Сыну двадцать три года. Муж Гульсун работает в котельне. Гульсун же разводит овец. Гульсун хотела бы купить телёнка. Поэтому она обратилась за кредитом.
Бубуайше тридцать восемь лет. Муж Бубуайши сельский пастух. Бубуайша также дома держит скот и продаёт молоко. У них трое детей. Младшему всего два годика. Бубуайша надеется получить кредит и купить ещё одну корову. 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Gulnara O. is the leader of this group. She is 43 years old. In these difficult times, with unemployment everywhere, and with many people at a loss for what to do, the example set by Gulnara is quite inspiring.

Unlike many others she didn't just sit around and complain about her situation or look for someone else to hire her. She and her husband quickly realized that now is the time when people must create their own jobs - simple businesses that are easy to develop without the need for large upfront investments. Their parents were also able to help out since they had the experience and the means to support the initiatives of their children. It's been fifteen years now that Gulnara and her husband have their own livestock breeding business.

Her husband had worked as a shepherd all his life. Currently he tends the herds and Gulnara manages the sale of their livestock. They raise and sell sheep. This was the business of their parents and they were the ones that first suggested to Gulnara and her husband to start raising their own livestock.

Gulnara raised three children. Her eldest daughter is already married. She is twenty-three years old. Her middle son is twenty-two. He is a construction worker in the city of Bishkek. The youngest daughter is fifteen and is a high school student. It was the livestock business that allowed Gulnara and her husband to purchase a house as well as have a wedding for their daughter. Currently their monthly income is around 2000 soms which is very little. However, the livestock that they already have allows Gulnara to look optimistically towards the future. Currently she has plans to buy another cow. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to complete this purchase.

These are Gulnara's group partners: Bakir is 43 years old and has been in the livestock business for thirteen years. His wife works from home selling various household items. They have three children. All of the children attend school and afterwards help their father with work around the house. Bakir would like to purchase a calf that he could raise and sell. Gulsun is 47 and she has one son who is twenty-three. Gulsun's husband works at the heating station. Gulsun herself raises sheep. She would like to buy a cow calf and that's the reason for her loan request. Bubuaysha is 38. Her husband is a shepherd. Bubuaysha also has some livestock at home and sells milk. They have three chidren. The youngest one is two years-old. Bubuaysha hopes to get a loan to purchase an additional cow.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.


Translated from Russian by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Livestock purchase to increase future earnings

loans.name: Phum

texts.en: Mrs. Phum O. is a villager in Sman Pream village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice for earning a living. Her husband, Mr. Suk Eom, is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to help support the family. Mrs. Phum O. has six children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, while another one is a construction worker, and the others are attending the local school. Although they try to work hard, they still spend a lot on transportation to go to work, so Mrs. Phum O. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her children to go to work, which will reduce their expenses. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to reduce expenses.

loans.name: Khom

texts.en: Mrs. Khom K. lives in Sman Pream village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 0.5-hectare plot to cultivate rice. Aside from this small farm, she is a pig breeder. Since her pig business is going well, she wants to expand it. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Khom K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase five more piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family living with this loan. She is a widow with two children who are both employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: to purchase five more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita O. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old. Teresita is married and has 3 school-age children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2002, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida M. is from the village of Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental. She is 31 years old. Nida is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Nida owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nida has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In November 2009, Nida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Nida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Diosdado

texts.en:
Mr. Diosdado C. has been engaged in his vegetable-vending business for almost seven years. He usually earned a net income of 400 Philippine pesos. But due to the high cost of commodities, his income is not enough for their daily needs; thus, he desires a third loan cycle with a loan of 5,000 pesos for additional working capital for his business. His wife sells rice cakes in their village and earns 200 pesos daily. He wants to expand his vegetable plantation to harvest more commodities to sell.

Diosdado and his wife reside in the village of Culalabat, Cauayan City, together with their three children. Two of his kids are enrolled in the elementary level of education, while his youngest is only 3 years old.

loans.use: Additional capital for his vegetable business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sann

texts.en: Mrs. Sann M. lives in Hang Heng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Ung Vannak, is a coconut seller. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support their family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sann M. is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This couple has four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia S. is from the village of Tonggo, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Lydia owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lydia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros T., a 45-year-old mother of five children who go to school or work, owns a small wooden house and a grocery shop where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, and gasoline. Ros retails her inventory to both passers-by and her neighbors.  She has been running the enterprise for a long time and earns an average of $5 a day. To ensures that the entire family has financial stability, her husband works hard in construction.  Ros T. is requesting her loan to increase her inventory and to buy an old motorbike for touring purposes.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and to buy an old motorbike for touring purposes

loans.name: Eda

texts.en: Eda B. is from the village of Calaca-an. She is 42 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Eda owns and operates a business raising ducks for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Eda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Eda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 11th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, a 55-year-old businesswoman, is married to Marcelino, who manages their farm lot in their village. They have three children, all married and living separately from them. She hopes and prays that they will remain healthy and strong to be able to provide for the needs of their own families.

Rebecca, who raises hogs, wants to grow her business by purchasing additional piglets to raise and so is requesting a loan of PHP6,000 from Kiva lenders. In addition to hog raising, Rebecca sells vegetables in their village, her income from this being used for the basic needs of their family. She hopes to expand both businesses to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets

loans.name: Kolab

texts.en: Mrs. Kolab I. lives in Thommoney village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a field to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Uy Thorn, is a fisherman. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Kolab I. decided to ask for a loan to buy a buffalo for breeding and for plowing the field. Mrs. Kolab I. is the mother of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, another is a construction worker, and the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a buffalo for breeding and for plowing the field.

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina, a tricycle operator and a load retailer within the village of Rizal Santiago City, is married to Ruben and they are blessed with three children: Rose Marie - 13 years old; Ruben Jr.- 12 years old, and Roanne - seven years old.

Ludivina is thankful because her husband is very industrious, each of them having their own responsibilities at home. She would like to improve their standard of living through additional capital, so she is requesting a loan of Php9,000 from Kiva lenders. This loan amount will serve as a big help in achieving her goal.

loans.use: Additional capital for motorcycle transport

loans.name: James

texts.en: James O. Oduor, 45 yrs old, has been in metal working for 12 years.  His business is called Lunjre Welders and he makes window frames, kiosks, gates and school equipment.  His business is located on the edge of a slum on Nyalenda Street outside Kisumu, and his clients are house builders and schools.  He has two full-time employees and three student apprentices (an apprentice is in the photo with James). James' main challenges are security for his shop and periodic power outages.  His long term business goal is to buy a container to secure his goods and to manufacture kiosks on a larger scale.  He is married to a shopkeeper and they have seven children ranging from three to 17 yrs old.  James describes himself as a hardworking entrepreneur and he hopes to educate all of his children.

loans.use: Raw materials to construct kiosks

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey N. lives in ThommoN. village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice, and she is also a water lily seller. Her husband, Mr. Oem Savuth, is a teacher who can make a small salary to support the family. He spends a lot of moN. on transportation because his work place is far from home. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Srey N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to ride to work. Mrs. Srey N. has three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study because this child is only four years old. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband to ride to work.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Amer

texts.en: Amer is an enterprising young shoe salesman from Palestine. He runs a successful business selling men’s and women’s shoes .At his shop he sells everything from soccer cleats and slippers to dress shoes. The shoe shop is situated in one of the most popular streets in Nablus city, which helps Amer's shoe-sale business. Still he needs a loan of $3000 to buy merchandise to add more supplies, allow him to offer a wider selection to his customers and to continue growing his business. He is thankful for your support

loans.use: Buy more merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is 30 years old and a food vendor.  She sells different kinds of street foods and barbecue in their village located in front of their house.  Her daily net income is PHP300.  With her desire to improve her business, she is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP5,000 that she can use as additional capital for her business. With this amount, she can purchase different merchandise and strengthen her food vending business in order to sustain their daily needs.

She is married and blessed with three children who are all in the elementary level.  She is working hard in order to increase her income and for her business to grow.

loans.use: Additional capital for the improvement of her food vending business

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
This is Lorena A., a young entrepreneur from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  She is 33 years old.  Her husband Joey, 36, is also a vendor.  

Lorena owns and manages a general store and sells various toys for children. She earns P4,000.00 a month.
