She applied for a new loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for P10,000.00 as additional capital for her business.  She’ll be purchasing new toy designs.  It has been Lorena’s long sought after dream to have her own toy store in a big shopping mall.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase new toy designs

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
Analie N. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Analie is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Analie owns & operates a specialized retail store selling bags and other ready to wear items in the local community. Analie has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Analie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jumakul's Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Jumakul, 56 years old. For 10 years, she and her husband have been breeding livestock and trading in sheep. Then they invested about twelve dollars to purchase cattle. This investment has turned into a monthly income, which is 10 times more than the original amount. They have raised three children. The eldest daughter, 32 and the middle son, 27, both are married and live separately. The little son, 22, is a college student. He is the only one who still lives with parents. Jumakul’s husband stays at home and is busy looking after cattle, whereas Jumakul goes to the cattle market and she is the one who makes all the purchase and sale deals. They used to keep and sell sheep. Afterwards they switched to horses. Animal husbandry has appeared to be a quite profitable business for Jumakul and her husband as due to it, they have been able to give all their children a proper education and marry their daughter. In recent times, Jumakul and her husband have noticed the tendency of people to buy sheep more than they do horses, as they are cheaper. They have applied for this loan and hope that by means of this loan they will be able to invest it in purchasing and breeding sheep. They hope to increase the total population of their cattle and marry their son in the near future. Jumakul has three partners: Duishokan, 44, is a mother of two children. Her husband works as a taxi-driver. Duishokan stays at home and looks after cattle. She breeds a special strain of sheep called “Gissar strain”. Duishokan needs a loan to purchase one more sheep of that kind. Zinagul, 50, and her husband work as dentists. They have four children. Zinagul is making preparations for her son’s wedding. Therefore, she has applied for this loan to buy a sheep. Nestandarajan, 47, is a housewife. She keeps some cattle at home and sells milk. Her spouse is a schoolteacher. He teaches geography. Nestandarajan needs a loan to buy milk.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase and breed sheep

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en: Anatalia M. is from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Anatalia owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over eighteen years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month. In 2005, Anatalia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Anatalia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thy O. lives in Thommoney village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) piece of land on which she cultivates rice.

Mrs. Thy O. is a widow with five children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. Now she has decided to ask fO. a loan to buy a motorbike fO. her children to use to go to work to reduce expenses.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use to go to work

loans.name: Chhouy

texts.en: Chhouy S. is a 47-year-old widow and mother. She was married, but divorced her husband when her four kids were young. She is a hard working woman who never wastes time in order to earn money to feed her school-aged children. She currently uses her old motorbike to pick up a variety of flowers to sell along the streets around the city. She usually makes $5 of profit a day to meet the needs of her kids, including studying fees and foods. Chhouy S. will be using a Kiva loan to accrue capital for her business of selling flowers.

loans.use: To accrue capital for selling-flowers business

loans.name: Mrs. Rathana Khaem Group

texts.en: Four people, who live in Chrouy Ampil village in Kandal province, make up this group loan. They will each use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Rathana K. is the group leader and she sells scarves. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more scarves to resell. Her husband, Mr. Heng Sovann, is employed in a small position at a small company. Mrs. Rathana K. has a child who is too young to work or study because this child is only two years old.

loans.use: To buy more scarves to resell.

loans.name: Mrs. Channa Ry Uong Group

texts.en: Mrs. Channa Ry U. is a group leader of six people, and they all live in Damnak village in Takeo province. Mrs. Channa Ry U. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. However, the soil is infertile, and in order to deal this problem, Mrs. Channa Ry U. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice field. Her husband, Mr. Teng Sokheng, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Channa Ry U. is a mother of three children who all attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the rice field.

loans.name: Mrs. Moun Sott Group

texts.en: Mrs. Moun S. lives in Tuol Kdei village in Kandal province, and is part of the Mrs. Moun S. Group. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare field of land where she cultivate rices. She is requesting a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizers for rice cultivating. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living with this loan. Mrs. Moun S. is a widow with three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another attends the local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizers for rice cultivating.

loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Yoeurn P. is single and lives in Kandal Leu village in Kandal province. She is a grocer. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy grocery goods to sell to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods to sell to earn more income.

loans.name: Melituna

texts.en:
Melituna P. is a 57-year-old businesswoman from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  She lives with her husband Eugenio, a pensioner and their three children, one of whom is still in college.

Melituna owns a general store located in their house. She is also into direct selling of cosmetics products.  She earns at least P5,000.00 a month from these combined business activities.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for two years, since 2007.  Now on her ninth loan cycle, she applied for a loan of P8,000.00 from  CCT to purchase more cosmetics products for her clients.  She will also use a portion of the funds for her child’s education.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. 

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn D. S. is 34 years old. Her husband Alexander D. S., 36 years old, is working abroad as an OFW. In order to provide for his family, he endures the pain of being away from his family. Because they need to send their children (Ahljohn, 14 years old; Juana Alaine, 13 years old and Ashlie Joyce, 8 years old) to school, they need more money to spend on educational expenses. In order to help her husband who suffers from being away from them, Jocelyn runs a business selling different kinds of jewelry. This business has been running for five years and continues to give them enough income for their daily expenses.

She became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) in 2005 and since then she always used every loan that she received to improve this business. Now she is requesting another loan to use for this business. She will buy different jewelry to sell in her store.

Jocelyn really works hard to make her plans of having another outlet of her store come true. She saves some of the revenue of the store so that she can increase the capital that she will use in her plan. She dreams that they can send all their children to school through college just from the revenue of her business so her husband is not far away from them.

loans.use: To buy more jewelry to sell

loans.name: Ream

texts.en: S., 48, is a local banana trader who has been doing this business for eight years. S. always leaves from her home to buy bananas in bulk from planters and retails them to make her income. Her husband is a cook who is hired by people to cook meals for their parties.  S. has five teenage children. One of her sons works cooking food and the other four are dependent on her. Recently, S. ordered bananas on credit from her supplier and she doesn’t have enough money to pay her supplier. Thus, she would like a loan in order to pay the bill for the bananas.

loans.use: To pay for bananas to resell

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena O. is from the village of Lawis Panalsalan. She is 61 years old, is married and has three adult children.

Lucena owns and operates a business building "nipa"-huts, houses built of palm trees, where many of the local community members live. She often works in the field with palm trees, weaving the leaves to form the roofs. Lucena has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Lucena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.

Lucena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in tools to expand her hut-building business

loans.name: Yet

texts.en: Mrs. Yet M. lives in Troey Troeng village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Soth Soeng, is a fisherman, however, he does not have enough fishnets to fish. Thus, Mrs. Yet M. decided to ask for loan to buy more fishnets to support her husband’s business and she will use the rest of loan to buy a motor machine for her husband's boat. Mrs. Yet M. is a mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because this child is only 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets, and a motor for her husband's boat.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
At the age of 63 and already a widow, Norma B. is still fighting against poverty for herself, her children (Erlinda, 41 years old; Edgardo, 39 years old; Armand, 35 years old; Elionor, 32 years old; and Lauriano, 29 years old) and her grandchildren.

Although most of her children now have their own work, Norma still continues to run her business, which is the selling of different school and office supplies, and also selling different foods that they personally prepare. These two businesses that they have contribute to the income that they can use for their expenses.

Every loan that she has received since she became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) is always used properly for the improvement of her businesses. Now, her 7th loan will be used in her business of selling school supplies. She will buy different school and office supplies that are really needed by the students in their school.

Norma’s plan is to improve the school and office supplies sales business because she wants to save so that their dreams of having a computer shop will be possible. This is really their dream because, in their place, it is really in demand.

loans.use: To buy different school and office supplies to sell in her store

loans.name: Kha

texts.en: Mrs. Kha A. lives in Ta Pov village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Vith Tab, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate rice. They have a problem with the soil, so Mrs. Kha A. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers and pesticides for cultivating rice. She hopes to increase their rice revenue and improve the family's living. She is a mother of five children, two of whom breed pigs, two are enrolled the local school, and the youngest is only two years old.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pesticides for cultivating rice.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en: This is Rosalinda M. (the woman in the black shirt), a single parent entrepreneur from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. Her two children are both married already and have families of their own. Rosalinda is among the government-accredited retailers of rice in Caloocan City. She always gets tired from attending to her business but finds consolation in helping her neighbors. She earns more than P 10,000.00 a month. Rosalinda is among the pioneer members of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in Caloocan City. She has been enjoying its many social benefits for community members. She is now her group’s community coordinator. The loans from the cooperative provide stability to her business. She can now purchase rice stocks in advance from a government-operated warehouse at a lower cost. She is currently in need of additional capital in the amount of P 29,000.00 to purchase more rice stocks. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy G. is from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Joy owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month. In 2009, Joy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Joy is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita V. is now 53 years old and married to Carlos V., 58 years old, who is now working as a tricycle (a type of cab in the Philippines that has three wheels) driver. They were blessed with five children, namely: Liberty, 30 years old; Carmita, 28 years old; Elmer, 27 years old; Carlota, 21 years old; and Carla May, 16 years old.

Their 3 oldest children are now working and the two youngest children will hopefully finish their studies in college. This is one of their dreams, that at least two of their children would become degree holders. That is why they’re striving hard.

In order to augment the meagre revenue of her husband from working as a driver, Nenita runs a food preparation business. She is the one who personally prepares the food for selling. This business has run for 20 years now and she really wants this to continue for many years because this gives them additional income and has become a part of her life.

She became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) in 1995 and every loan that she received from this institution is used to improve her business. Now, her 7th loan will be used again to improve this business. She will use this for buying different things that will help to diversify her menu. She is hoping that all the things that she will buy using the loan will help her business to grow more.

Now, Nenita’s dream is that she has been able to save for the education of her two children. She really wants to give their children a better future and that is why they work really hard. And also she hopes that someday they will be able to renovate their house so they can experience living in a better house.

loans.use: To finance her food preparation business

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en: Mrs. Sokheng P. lives in Preaek Ta Sau village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. However, her field is infertile and she does not have rice seed to grow. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and rice seed, and she will use the rest of money to buy chickens for breeding. Mrs. Sokheng P. is a widow with four children: one is employed in a garment factory, one is a laborer, and the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed, as well as chickens for breeding.

loans.name: Jerop

texts.en: Jerop S. runs a successful Safaricom kiosk with her husband.  They offer Mpesa (bill paying by cell phone), pre-paid cell phone cards, photocopying, mobile phones and mobile phone charging.  Her business is called Qamara and it has been running for two years and they have two employees.  Her advantage is that she often has electricity when many of her competitors don't, but she still struggles with network issues and some power failures.  Jerop's goal is to open more branches and buy more computers to offer internet services. The couple have one baby boy and they would like to build a house for their family.

loans.use: To increase the "float" for Mpesa services

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.en:
Wilfredo is 50 years old and is married to Ofelia. They are blessed with four children: Wilmer, who is 23 years old and an undergraduate in college; Rowell, who is 19 years old and a high school graduate; John, who is 17 years old; and Waren, who is 15 years old.

Wilfredo is a tricycle driver and also a farmer in their community. Using his tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar for transporting passengers), he is usually able to provide the needs of his family, but due to the high cost of commodities and other expenditures, he couldn’t provide all the needs of his family this time. He was encouraged to join the program so that he could ask for financial support from the Kiva lenders.

He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP. This amount will help him a lot to improve the business he has. He is sacrificing going to and from the market to earn income. The loan will be used for the maintenance and repairs of his tricycle to avoid any breakdowns and to make it more comfortable to ride.

loans.use: For the maintenance of his motorcycle

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria C. is now 63 years old, still contented and happily living with her husband Aurelio C., 64 years old. In the long years of their marriage they were given three children: Fernando, 39 years old; Zenaida, 36 years old and Rowelio, 33 years old. One frustration for Gloria and her husband is that their children only attained a low level of education.

A good thing is that their two sons are now working abroad, so they will be able to send their children to school until college. Naturally, Gloria and Aurelio don’t want their children to experience what they experienced in the past. Gloria, in her own little way, helps their children to make their dream possible for her grandchildren. She has run a variety store business for seven years, and she really wants this to continue and to grow more. In 2002 she joined the Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), and as a member she is entitled to loans. Every loan that she received in the past years of being a member was always used in improving her variety store business. Now her loan will be used to expand her business, because she will buy all the necessary things needed by her business like sacks of rice, different groceries and many more. She is hoping that her business will grow so that they can turn it into a grocery store that can sell more things than a variety store. In that way, she could help her children in sending their children to school, and also help themselves improve their life.

loans.use: To finance her variety store business

loans.name: Kunthy

texts.en: Mrs. Kunthy S. lives in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Ban Popheap, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Kunthy S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers and pesticides, and she will use the rest of the money to buy a irrigation machine to water the field. Mrs. Kunthy S. is a mother of a child who is too young to work or study because this child is only two years old.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers, pesticides, and a watering machine.

loans.name: Dany

texts.en: Dany M. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. He is married and has three children. He runs a food shop at Buguruni community in Dar es Salaam. Dany purchases and sells a variety of goods to customers including wheat flower, maize flower, beans, sugar and cooking oil. He purchases the goods for his business from wholesale and retail shops and then sells it to retail customers. Dany is able to meet his family's daily needs thanks to his business income. He has been in the business for five years and is requesting a loan of TZS 800,000 to buy more inventory to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy inventory to expand his business

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina N. is from the village of  Pala-o, Iligan City. Ludivina is 37 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ludivina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Ludivina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ludivina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ludivina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ludivina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nhorn

texts.en: Mrs. Nhorn N. lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. She faces an obstacle with her plantation, because her field is infertile. Thus, Mrs. Nhorn N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and she will use the rest of money to hire a laborer to plow the field. She is a widow with two children who are both laborers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and a laborer to plow the field.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Sun S. A. is 31 years of age and the good mother of three children. One of her children is married and the other two are dependent on her income. Sun S. A. sells bananas to earn a living and her husband works as a military policeman. In order to generate more income, Sun S. A. hopes to encourage her husband to hold another job as a Tuk Tuk driver. She is therefore applying for a loan of US$1000, which her husband will be able to use as capital to buy a trailer-motorcycle to begin offering Tuk Tuk services.

loans.use: To buy a trailer-motorcycle for Tuk Tuk services

loans.name: Mrs. Ha Ut Group

texts.en: Mrs. Ha U. is a group leader of four and they all live in Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province. Mrs. Ha U. is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Soy Roem, is a construction worker. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still don't earn enough income to support the family's living. In order to improve the family's living, Mrs. Ha U. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She is 24 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because this child is only one year old.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza B. is 31 years old and married to Bernaldo. Her husband works in Malaysia as a fisherman. Even though it means they are far from each other, they sacrifice their happiness because they want their family to have a good future. They have been blessed with one child named Bernaflor. Flordeliza is now experiencing difficulties because she is the only one looking after her child's needs. She also has problems with a myoma or ovarian cyst. But even though she is ill, she is still looking for something that will serve as a source of income.

Flordeliza is engaged in direct selling of Avon cosmetics and apparel products. She is always looking for customers around her village to buy the products she sells. She sells house to house in order to have more customers. She believes that the more customers she has, the more income she earns because, with more customers, she sells more products. She wants to borrow 5,000 Philippine pesos for additional capital to buy more products to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more products to sell

loans.name: Greshiel

texts.en:
Greshiel M. is 45 years old and from the village of Bolisong, Kinoguitan Misamis Oriental. Greshiel is separated from her spouse and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Greshiel owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products, such as fish balls. She also sells stick brooms in the local community. Greshiel has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Greshiel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Greshiel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Greshiel is requesting another loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Greshiel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mary Chris

texts.en: Mary Chris is from the village of Calacaan. She is 22 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Mary Chris owns and operates a business planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Mary Chris joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Mary Chris is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 47 years old and the mother of five children. Her family lives in the village of San Isidro, Ilagan, Isabela. For a year now, Mary has sold barbecue and other street foods in their village.  Her business has grown to the point where she is able to generate an income that covers her family's daily needs. However, she still wants her business to further progress, so she can save little by little for emergency purposes, especially since she and her husband are not getting any younger. Therefore, she is asking for a loan amounting to Php 6,000 from KIVA lenders for her business expansion. She knows that there are many people who are generous enough to help the needy like her, so she is optimistic that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: To expand her barbecue and street food business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema R. is a married Tanzanian businesswoman. She runs a café selling a variety of baked and fried foods and soft drinks in the Tandika district in Dar es Salaam.  The goods are purchased from the city markets and the soft drinks from the soft drinks agency. They are bought wholesale and retail.  She has been in the business for five years and she manages to meet her daily family and business needs with the income. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita H., 53 years old, is married to Julio, who operates a welding shop in their village. They have three children who are all college graduates. The couple live in Zone III, San Mariano, Isabela. Tita hopes that their children will have a good future even without her and Julio's supervision anymore. Now that they are done with their studies she believes that they could make it on their own. However, Tita is ready to assist her children if they need her.

Tita makes a living through her poultry business. She raises chicks and sells them after 30 days. Aside from this, she also sells vegetables, fishes, meats and other commodities in their village, which she has been doing since their children entered college. Through her business, she generates an income of Php4,000 monthly which is also a big help in sustaining the daily needs of her family. She is asking for a loan of Php 4,000 from KIVA lenders for her poultry and vegetable businesses. She hopes that her businesses will further expand with the help of this loan.

loans.use: To expand her poultry and food sales businesses

loans.name: Florence Wahito

texts.en:
Florence N., 41 years old and married with four children, has a small shop in Kibera where she sells sugar, maize flour, and rice to her customers in Kibera's slums. She has been in the business for  about two years and has been able to earn a profit of about  20,000 Kenya Shillings per month. This is enough to sustain both herself and her family.

She was with another microfinance institution, but the group was destabilized by the post-election violence, so she joined KADET. Florence intends to use her loan to add more stocks of sugar, maize flour, and rice to meet the demand of her clients. She hopes to grow the business to a level where she can serve her customers with a stock of about 200,000 Kenya shillings.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To add stock of  sugar, soaps, maize flour and rice

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita O., 38, is the mother of four children, three of whom are still studying. She is engaged in the transportation business, owning a passenger tricycle which her husband operates. It has been their source of income for three years, providing the means of support for their family. Margarita is requesting a loan of Php4,000 from Kiva lenders for their business.

To help her husband make a living, Margarita operates a manicure service in their village. Aside from this, she also sells personal collection products. She hopes to expand her own business someday if given the chance.

loans.use: To maintain the transportation business

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa describes herself as a walking vendor in their village. She has been engaged in selling frozen foods such as ham, hotdogs, tocino, etc., which she sells door to door in their village. (Tocino is sweetened cured pork, similar to bacon.) To purchase more frozen products and increase her income she wants to borrow 6,000 PHP from Kiva lenders.

Elsa is a 37-year-old business woman who lives in Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela, together with her family. She and her husband have been helping each other to provide the needs of their children. The couple’s greatest dreams for their children are that they finish their studies in college and have a good future. They hope that through their business, they can reach their dreams for their family.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely T. is 50 years old and lives in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. She is a married woman and has two children who are both studying. Like every parent’s dream, she also wishes to provide a complete education for her two children. She hopes that her business and her husband’s business can contribute to the attainment of their dreams. 

Mely has been raising hogs as her way of living for a very long time. She lets her sow get pregnant and raises new hogs. This way, she can make more savings after selling her piglets. She feeds them with special feeds, and according to her, she needs additional capital to buy a supply of feeds for her grown-up pigs. She is borrowing at least 4,000 PHP for her piggery. She is hoping that lenders will grant her requested loan.

loans.use: To buy supply of feeds

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios N. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Remedios owns and operates a business making and selling food. She sells specialty food products in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Remedios joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen G. is from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Helen owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-six years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month. In 2005, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Helen is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina B. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old and married with seven adult children. To make a living, Dina owns and operates a business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Dina has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately $175 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Dina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Dina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sol Phat Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of thirteen people and is located in Khnar Thum village in Takeo province. All of the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sol P. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, she is also a weaver. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy raw materials to support her business. Mrs. Sol P. is a 55 year old widow with four children, two of whom are laborers while the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to support her business.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en: Habiba H. is a married Tanzanian businesswoman. She runs a business at Tandika district in Dar es Salaam. She purchases and sells a variety of clothes to customers. The business goods are purchased from the wholesale and retail shops and then she resells to her customers. She has been in the business for four years and her business profits allow her to meet her daily needs. She needs a loan of  600,000 TZS to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
At the age of 26, Marites is engaged in the general store business in her village of Nungnungan, Cauayan City, earning a daily net income of Php150.00. She is also selling barbecue in front of her retail store, which earns her Php250 daily. Because Marites desires to acquire more income, she is requesting a loan of Php 4,000 to add some grocery items to her store to increase her income in order to give assistance to the education of her children.

Marites is a widow, having lost her husband this past April. Moving on is very difficult for her as she struggles to have a good life without him. She has two children: her eldest, Matt, six years of age, is a Grade One pupil, and Joshua is four years old. She hopes that some generous lenders will grant her loan as soon as possible.

loans.use: Additional capital for her retail store

loans.name: Afaayo Development Of Lugazi Group

texts.en:
Z. Elisa is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 35 years old and married with four children between the ages of 12 and 2, and he also takes care of two orphans.

Elisa has been a compound designer and attendant (lawn and house maintenance) in Kiira, Kyaliwajjala for eight years, and he is able to make an average of $54 a week. He has his own customers that are just a call away in case they need his services. His main challenge is the dry season, when the grass takes a long time to grow, and the holidays, when families involve themselves in cleaning their homes. He is liked by his clients because of his tidiness and his time management skills.

Elisa would like to turn his business into a company and wants to educate all his children to the University level. He needs a loan to be able to buy fuel to be used in his machines and to buy a hoe and a rake. Elisa is a hard-working and friendly man.

loans.use: Buying fuel and tools to be used in his business.

loans.name: Khuk

texts.en: Khuk P. sells Khmer noodles to earn a living. She sells her food to neighbors for their breakfast and usually earns about $5 each day to help meet her family’s food needs. In her business, three of her school-aged kids assist her in selling noodles when they are free from studying. In addition, her husband works as a clothes-sewer from home (he appears in the picture). Khuk P. will use her loan to purchase essential ingredients for her business, as well as to buy equipment for her husband’s tailoring business.

loans.use: For ingredients for her business, and equipment for her husband’s tailoring business

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene P. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $150 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Arlene is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna C. is from the village of Talisay. She is 29 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Lorna owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Lorna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the daily needs of her family and the education of her children. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Puthy Pen Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eighteen people who all live in Khnar Thum village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Puthy P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members and they will each use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectare of land where she cultivates rice. She is also a weaver, and owns a small grocery store at home. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more raw materials and more grocery products to resell to earn more income. Mrs. Puthy P. is a 48 year old widow with a child who is enrolled in the local school. All the members are presented in the picture but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials and more grocery products to resell to earn more income.

loans.name: Nyanawon

texts.en:
Nyanawon N. is currently in the business of buying and selling bread, and is requesting a loan to purchase soft drinks like sodas, water, and juice to sell.  Nyanawon is 30 years old married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks like sodas, water and juice to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Pov Daok Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nineteen people, who all live in Khnar Thum village in Takeo province. Mrs. Srey Pov D. is the village bank president and was selected by the members.

She breeds pigs as a business. She is also a weaver. Now, she needs some money to buy more raw materials to support her business. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living with this loan. Mrs. Srey Pov D. is 41 years old widow with four children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to support her business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita M. is from the village of Tag-ibo, Iligan City. She is 54 years old and married. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mabelle

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame est mariée à un ingénieur et le couple à un enfant. Pour aider financièrement son mari dans la gestion du foyer, elle s’est lancée l’année dernière dans le commerce de bijoux et de perles traditionnelles dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Elle s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé mais aussi au Ghana, où elle arrive à collecter des perles traditionnelles de bonne qualité. Elle dispose aussi de clientes fidèles à qui elle livre ses produits à domicile. Elle a approché WAGES pour pouvoir lancer de nouvelles commandes ; ce crédit lui permettra d’acheter des perles et bijoux en nombre considérable.
texts.en:
This is a young lady who is married to an engineer. The couple has one child. To help her husband financially to manage the household, she got started last year in the commerce of traditional jewelry and pearls at the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé. She stocks up at the Grand Market of Lomé but also in Ghana, where she manages to collect good quality traditional pearls. She also has loyal customers to whom she delivers her goods to their homes. She approached WAGES to be able to initiate new orders; this loan will enable her to buy pearls and jewelry in major quantities.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewelry

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie S. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old and single. To make a living, Jessie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a variety store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of food and daily use products in the community. Jessie has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jessie joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessie is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her store

loans.name: Shelly

texts.en:
Shelly A. is a Tanzanian businessman. He is married with three school-aged children. He runs a vegetable garden at Tabata Kimanga district in Dar es Salaam, where he grows and sells different types of green vegetables.

Shelly purchases vegetable seeds from agricultural seed shops in the city's shopping center and elsewhere. He sells his vegetables both wholesale and retail. With his business profits, he is able to meet his family's daily needs. Shelly wants to increase production by buying an irrigation water pump that can cover a wide area of irrigation. He needs a loan of 800,000 TZS to buy this equipment.

loans.use: To purchase an irrigation water pump

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhom Seth Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen people who are all living in Lvea Sa Kraom village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Sokhom S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Sokhom S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows vegetables. Now she wants to grow beans on her field but she does not have enough money to pay for them. Thus, she decided to request for a loan to buy bean seeds and she will use the rest of loan to hire laborers to work on the field.

Mrs. Sokhom S. is also a teacher in the local school. She is 55 years old and is a widow with a child who is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy bean seeds and to hire laborers to work on her field

loans.name: Arcelie

texts.en:
Arcelie M. is from the village of Tag-ibo, Iligan City. She is 40 years old, married and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, Arcelie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products, such as local delicacies, in the local community. Arcelie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Arcelie joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Arcelie plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Ret Pha Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of eighteen people, is located in Lvea Sa Kraom village in Kandal province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Ret P. is the village bank president. She is 31 years old and the mother of four children who are attending the local school. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she grows vegetables.

Mrs. Ret P.’s husband, Mr. Un Sovann, is a vegetables middleman. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Ret P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables for him to resell to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her husband to resell

loans.name: Minaw

texts.fr: Cette femme est une veuve qui a à sa charge l’éducation scolaire de ses 05 enfants ; en 1990, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de céréales, de sucre, d’huile d’arachide et de divers autres produits. Ce commerce lui permet désormais de se prendre en charge et de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. Elle vend ses produits en face du marché de Dabarakondji à Lomé. Elle accueille bien ses clients qui viennent en tout temps effectuer des achats chez elle. En ce moment elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 sacs de maïs, 05 sacs de haricot, 02 sacs de sucres, 03 sacs de farine et divers autres produits.
texts.en:
This woman is a widow who has the responsibility of educating her five children. In 1990, she embarked on commerce in grains, sugar, peanut oil, and various other products. This business now allows her to support herself and to provide for her children. She sells her products across from the Dabarakondji market in Lomé. She does a good job accommodating her customers, who come to her at any time to make their purchases. Right now, she’s requesting a WAGES loan to buy 5 sacks of corn, 5 sacks of beans, 2 sacks of sugar, 3 sacks of flour, and a variety of other goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains, oil, salt, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Jeralyn

texts.en:
Jeralyn M. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 26 years old, married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Jeralyn owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community, such as baked pastries and electronic (prepaid cellphone) loads. Jeralyn also runs a used clothing business.

In 2008, Jeralyn joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Jeralyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her third from HSPFI.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Youk

texts.en:
Youk P. is a rattan cupboard maker who is 61 and is a good mother caring for six children. Four of them are married and live independently, while the other two are single (a daughter is a garment worker and a son works making rattan). Youk P. was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. Youk P. and her son are shown in the photo.

Since 2006, Youk P. has owned a small handicraft business. She makes rattan cupboards for sale, a skill she earned from her grandmother. Recently, Youk P. built a medium-sized stall behind her house where she plans to raise female ducks in order to produce eggs for sale. Because she doesn’t have enough money to make that possible, she seeks a loan from Kiva through HKL to be used to buy many ducks to begin breeding.

loans.use: To buy many ducks to begin breeding

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita S. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay Misamis Oriental. She is 66 years old and a widow with four adult children. To make a living, Purita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Purita has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately $63 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Purita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Purita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy an engine for the fishing boat.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma M., for the second time, is requesting a loan through ASHI, after paying her previous one funded by Kiva. This is because she wants her variety store business to grow, which it can do if she sells a wider variety of goods and beverages for the convenience of people in the community. She also hopes that along with satisfying her customers she will also be satisfying her family through her proceeds, by supporting their basic needs, and especially for the education of her grandchildren.

Most of Norma’s children have their own families now. Only her husband and her 31-year-old daughter are still living with her in their house. Being poor like her, she has no other options to find financial assistance besides from ASHI, because most of the money lenders are asking higher interest rates. The loan she is requesting is her only means to achieve all of her aspirations, both for the business and for her family.

loans.use: To purchase various beverages which will be sold in her store.

loans.name: Mr. Vinh Meourn Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of ten people and they all live in Vihear village in Takeo province. Mr. Vinh M. is the village bank president and was selected by the members. He is a fisherman and now he needs some money to buy more fish nets to earn more income. His wife, Mrs. Chhuon Minh, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. She also sells the fish from her husband's business. Mr. Vinh M. is 46 years old and the father of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more fish nets to earn more income.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma C. is requesting a larger loan through ASHI to grow her backyard poultry-raising business. "Backyard poultry" refers to raising just a small number of chicks, or less than the minimum number of chicks raised to be qualified as a poultry-raising business. It seemed too early for Elma to dream of having a full-fledged poultry business, considering the size of loan she is qualified to apply for at the moment.

Despite that, she positively sees that her future loans will grow even bigger as she strives to supplement the needs of her growing business. Elma also expects her profits to increase, which will enable her to support the financial needs of her son and his family, especially the education of her grandchildren.

She has nothing else to think about for herself, for she is already 72 years old and soon her life will be over. When that time comes, Elma wants to leave something to her son that will help him in supporting his family's financial needs, especially his children.

loans.use: To purchase chcken food and chicks to raise.

loans.name: Ayaba

texts.fr: Cette femme a ouvert dans sa maison une boutique de vente des produits d’alimentation générale ; son activité est située dans le quartier de Dabarakondji à Lomé, où elle réalise de très bonnes affaires. Elle accueille bien ses clients qui viennent en tout temps effectuer des achats chez elle. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 1994 ; grâce à ce commerce, elle arrive à apporter sa contribution dans la gestion de son foyer. Elle voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 cartons de petits pois, 10 cartons de tomates en boîtes,05 cartons de lait "PEAK", 10 cartons de pâtes alimentaires, des savons et divers autres produits. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
This is a woman who opened a store in her house to sell grocery items. Her business is located in the Dabarakondji district of Lomé where her commerce is going very nicely. She really accommodates her customers who come to her place at any time to make their purchases. She started this business in 1994. Thanks to this commerce, she manages to do her share in managing the household. She would like to obtain a WAGES loan to buy 5 boxes of peas, 10 boxes of canned tomatoes, 5 boxes of the milk "PEAK", 10 boxes of pasta, soap and other diverse products. She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains and a variety of foodstuff

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith B. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old and a widow with five adult children. To make a living, Judith owns and operates a business selling processed fish products in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $75 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Judith is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Lerb Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan, which consists of ten people, is located in Vihear village in Kandal province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Mao L. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder. Since her pigs are getting bigger and bigger, she needs some money to buy more pig food for her business. Her husband, Mr. Srei Chamroeun, is a fisherman. Mrs. Mao L. is 40 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more pig food for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: Suzana

texts.en: Suzana G. M. is a married Tanzanian businesswoman. She runs a clothing store at Tabata – Kimanga district in Dar es Salaam.  She sells different types of clothes to customers for men and women, youth and children. She first purchases the clothes from the wholesale and retail shops at Kariakoo city market and Karume city market. She needs a loan of 800,000 TZS to buy more goods to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita E., 40 years old, is the mother of five children whose ages range from 1 to 12 years old. Her husband is a fisherman while she is a fish vendor. Hand in hand the couple strives to bring their family out of poverty despite the unending obstacles they encounter. As they go through life, the vision of their children is their inspiration. Margarita and her husband want them to finish their education until college to be able to have a better career in the future.

As much as possible, Margarita, being their mother, would not want their children to experience life with less options because of poverty. To be able to achieve this dream, Margarita is working hard to grow her husband’s business as well as her own.

Through her membership in ASHI, loans she accesses are used properly to materialize every plan she and her husband have for the business. Someday, she positively believes that no matter how poor they are now, through their determination, unity and love to one another, they will be able to change their standard of living along and that of their children.

loans.use: To finace their fishing and fish-selling businesses

loans.name: Marcelita

texts.en:
Marcelita is engaged in a retailing business in which she sells different kinds of frozen foods such as tocino (a cured meat product native to the Philippines, usually made out of pork and similar to ham and bacon), longganisa (sausages flavoured with indigenous spices), hot dogs, and so on.

Her products are very consumable in their village and, for this reason, she would like to obtain additional revolving capital of Php 8,000 to increase her products as well as her profits. She hopes to expand her business to meet the demands of her customers. According to her, she will increase the number of frozen foods that she retails whenever her loan is granted.

Marcelita is a 30-year-old businesswoman. She is already married and has children of school age and hopes to be more profitable in her business to support the needs of her growing children. She and her husband are working hard just to attain their dream for their children which is that they finish their studies and have a good future someday. With their business, they know that they can reach their dreams.

loans.use: To buy more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Eya

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de chaussures dames ; cette vendeuse ambulante exerce cette activité dans le quartier de Bè Kpota à Lomé. Elle est connue de beaucoup de personnes, car vendant ses chaussures de maison en maison. Grâce à cette activité, elle arrive à apporter sa contribution financière à son mari qui est un soudeur pour l’éducation scolaire de leurs 02 enfants. Elle s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle sollicite en ce moment un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 cartons de chaussures dames.
texts.en:
This lady has a revenue-generating business selling women’s shoes. She is a traveling saleswoman in the Bè Kpota district in Lomé. Many people know her because of the shoes she sells from house to house. Thanks to this business, she manages to do her financial share for her husband, who is a welder, for educating their two children. She stocks up at the Grand Marketplace of Lomé. She’s requesting a loan from WAGES at this time to buy ten boxes of women’s shoes.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy footwear to sell

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora, 45, became a widow when she was twenty-five years old. Her principle in life is that no matter what happens, life must go on for the sake of her children. Nora is now living with Samuel Gonzales and she has two children with him. Their family lives together in the village of Zone III, San Mariano, Isabela.

Nora operates her own variety store in their village and in her small store she also sells frozen foods for additional income. She hopes that her store will further expand because it is very helpful to their family. Nora is requesting a loan of Php 5,000 in order to have additional capital for improving her business. She will use the loan to buy more commodities to sell. She hopes that through the help of the loan, her business will grow.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to improve her business

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en: Conchita M., 73 years old, and her husband are making portable folding beds for a business. They have been using plastic rattan which is one of the most common materials used in making living room chairs and tables as well as other house accessories in the Philippines.  This kind of furniture and accessories are salable to class C and middle-class people, like most of the people living in Antique province. Given the opportunity of having more capital through a loan, Conchita’s business could grow much further because they could have plenty of costumers.
