The proceeds will enable her to support her needs as well as her husband’s and grandchildren's.  At least, when her life ends, she will have prepared her children and grandchildren as well as husband to face their own lives and have the possibility of changing it through the business she worked hard for.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase necessary materials for making portable folding beds.

loans.name: Maribeth Mae

texts.en:
Maribeth Mae O. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old. Maribeth Mae is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maribeth Mae owns a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Maribeth Mae has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maribeth Mae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation with ability to engage in business activities. Maribeth Mae is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Maribeth Mae from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jearen

texts.en:
Jearen N. is already 29 years old and is married to Arnel who is a tricycle driver in their village. The couple has three children and two of them are presently studying. Their family lives peacefully in the village of Zone III, San Mariano, Isabela.

Jearen and her husband have been involved in the transportation business for two years. They own a tricycle which Arnel, her husband, operates. According to her, they need enough funds for the maintenance of their passenger tricycle. She hopes for a loan of at least PHP 4,000 to do it so. She hopes that her loan request will be granted because their business is the only source of income they have at the moment which is very helpful to their family.

loans.use: For the maintenance of their passenger tricycle

loans.name: Gacu

texts.en:
Gacu S. is currently in the business of selling maize and millet flour and is requesting a loan to buy more items like simsim, groundnut paste, etc. for sale. Gacu is 40 years old and is married to a prison officer. She has 10 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy more items like simsim, groundnut paste, etc. for sale

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Anabel is 24 years old and married to Christopher, who makes a living as a driver. They have two children who are both studying. Their eldest, Marc, is a high school student and their youngest is now a grade IV pupil. The couple hopes that their two children can finish their college studies because she knows that it is really important to have a college degree. As parents, they promise to do their best to help them achieve their dreams.

Anabel owns and manages a general store in their village. She just started her business last July and she is trying to make it progressive. Anabel said that she needs assistance to further expand her business thus she is requesting a loan of at least PHP 5,000 from KIVA lenders who are willing to help. She will use the loan in purchasing more grocery items for her little store and she hopes for it to be granted.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her store

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina L. is engaged in hog raising business. According to her, feed is consumed rapidly by her hogs. She wants to borrow a loan of at least PHP 4,000 to help her purchase a supply of feed, which costs more than a thousand for each sack. This amount will be very helpful in sustaining the needs of her hogs. Gina hopes that her business will grow and have more development someday. She hopes that the number of her hogs will increase through the assistance of KIVA lenders.

Gina is a married business woman and has school-aged children. They live together happily in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. Gina’s husband is also very cooperative and industrious. Her agricultural business is doing good and is also a big help to their family.

loans.use: To purchase supply of feed for her hogs

loans.name: Kiwamirembe Of Mukono Group

texts.en: M. Margaret is a 52-year-old lady who is married with 5 children aged 34 – 23 years, with only 1 child still at the University level. Margaret also helps to take care of her siblings, some of whom are in school. She is a business lady with a hardware shop in Wantoni and her main biggest challenge is having bad debtors that affect her business cash flow. Margaret is able to make 300,000 UGS as profits, and this is attributed to the good customer care and the available stock due to the use of loans. She has a dream of building rentals and educating her last child and her siblings to the highest level. She needs a loan to restock her hardware shop with more materials.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina C., 68 years old, lives with her husband and son in a very remote municipality of Antique province. Despite the inaccessibility of their municipality, being one of the farthest municipalities of the province, Angelina and her family have enjoyed having a very simple life and their bountiful environment.

However, Angelina is aware that life from now on will never be the same. Even in their village, several mining activities had opened and a lot of commercial establishments were built. Because of this industrialization, financial preparation occurred to Angelina. She has to be prepared financially for her 14-year-old son, whom she wants to graduate from college to be able to have a better career and to become competitive. Therefore, Angelina wishes to borrow a larger amount through ASHI to be able to grow her variety store and hog-raising business. Profits from her businesses will augment her husband’s small monthly honorarium as the village councilor. Aside from her son to support, Angelina also wants to support a lot of grandchildren and change their lives from poverty.

loans.use: Purchase softdrinks and other beverages for her variety store; purchase food for her pigs and necessary materials for rice farming.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en:
Olive D. V. is a hog raiser in the Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. She is requesting a loan of PHP 4,000 to sustain the needs of her hogs, which include feed and medicine. She hopes to expand her business through purchasing more hogs in the future. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to grow her business.

Olive is married and has five children, most of whom are studying. She is glad that they own a farm which is being managed by her husband. It helps them a lot in providing the daily needs of her children and also sustains their educational needs. She hopes that KIVA lenders will give her a chance to further improve her business and earn more income from it someday.

loans.use: Additional capital for her piggery

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: May

texts.en:
May M. is from the village of Pala-o, Iligan City. She is 35 years old. May is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, May owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. May has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, May joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and enable her to engage in business activities. May is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by May from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eufrecenia

texts.en:
Eufrecenia is a 47-year-old diligent businesswoman. She is married and has three school-aged children. Aside from farming, her husband is always busy catching fish from the river. This is his additional source of income, which meets their basic needs. Eufrecenia and her family live in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. 

Eufrecenia sells the fish that her husband catches. For more income, she also buys additional fish to sell in the market. She hopes to have additional capital of at least 4,000 Philippine pesos to increase the amount of fish that she sells. Eufrecenia hopes that her children could finish their studies. She knows that, as parents, her children need their financial support; that is why the couple joins hands to meet the educational needs of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette dame dispose d’une boutique dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé, où elle vend des produits de la brasserie de Lomé, comme des boissons alcoolisées et non alcoolisées. Elle vend aussi des produits yaourt appelés « Fan Milk » et des produits d’alimentation générale comme du sucre, des tomates, des pâtes alimentaires, des savons de toilettes. Elle réalise de bonnes affaires à cause de ses bonnes qualités d’accueil. Elle sollicite urgemment un crédit de WAGES pour commander des casiers de bière, des produits Fan Milk ainsi que certains produits d’alimentation générale. Elle n’est pas mariée mais a un enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
This is a lady who has a store at the Hédzranawoé marketplace in Lomé where she sells pub products, such alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. She also sells yoghurt products called “Fan Milk” and also grocery items, such as sugar, tomatoes, pasta, and bath soaps. Business is good because of her nice obliging qualities. She’s urgently requesting a WAGES loan to order cases of beer and Fan Milk products, as well as certain foodstuff. She is not married but has a child to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuff

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 43 years old. Gina is widowed and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gina makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling longaniza (Philippine pork sausage) and barbecue in the local community. Gina also runs a sari-sari (variety) store.

In 2009, Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase another business. Gina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to expand her longaniza business. This will be the third loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her and her children's daily needs.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
Mylene Q. is a loving mother of four children whose age ranges from 3 to 14 years old. Her husband is a laborer, while she runs a variety store. Mylene wishes that the small business she started will continuously grow until she finally reaches her dream of her children graduating from college. Despite her financial struggle caused by her family's poverty, Mylene has managed to keep her performance in ASHI in terms of repayment and business maintenance very good to be able to acquire a much larger loan amount for her next loan.

Her astute disposition in life and business is supported by her loving husband, because he knows that the profits Mylene makes out of her business are a great resource for the family's expenses. With this loan, Mylene plans to purchase necessary groceries and items to be sold in her store for the convenience of her customers.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase soft drinks, canned goods and other varieties of ready-to-cook food to be sold in her variety store

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina A. is from the village of Inobulan, Salay Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Rosalina is married and has adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosalina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa T. is not just concerned about her family's way of life, but she is also concerned about the way of life for many people in their village. Through her small variety store business, she hopes to make it more convenient for people to access their basic needs, especially food. Their village is very far and is inaccessible to transportation, markets and hospitals. These concerns led Teresa to think of a business that would help people in their village. Therefore, when she had access to a loan through her membership in ASHI, she put up a small variety store. From then on, her business has not only been helping her own family through her profits, but also other families through the access to goods that she has introduced.

Teresa wants to develop her business further through the loan she is requesting. She hopes that the time will come when her business will become sustainable and profitable to be able to achieve her personal dreams of educating her only child at college.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for the store.

loans.name: Gorgonia

texts.en:
Gorgonia Tnadug’s family income comes from rice farming and the selling of dried coconut or “kopra” in Filipino (Philippine language). It is her wish that her business will develop with the assistance of a loan. 

Her husband is a farm laborer and does not earn enough to take care of the daily needs of the family, especially the needs of their only child who is presently studying at college. For their child’s education to be sustained until graduation, Gorgonia regularly requests a loan through ASHI to develop her business' profits. Being poor, Gorgonia at times is hesitant to take out a larger loan from ASHI. However, her determination to bring her family out of poverty gives her the courage to face the consequences, including the interest rate of her loan. Eventually, she will overcome the obstacle of being poor. She is able to operate a few businesses, just in case one fails. 

Gorgonia will use the present loan for her hog raising and rice farming business. Income from her other business, selling “kopra” and vegetables, has enabled her to repay her loan from ASHI weekly including its interest. Seeing her only child continuously study in college is the fulfillment of the dream she keeps in her heart, and is the result of the hard work she does every day.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, feed, and supplies for rice farming.

loans.name: Patouani

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus le commerce de détail de médicaments génériques et de certains produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 2002 ; son activité est située devant sa maison dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Grâce à ses qualités d’accueil, elle arrive à fidéliser sa clientèle. Elle a approché WAGES pour acheter certains produits génériques manquants ainsi que des produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a une réelle assurance de rembourser le crédit dans les délais qui lui seront exigés.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of two children. Her revenue-generating business involves retail sales of generic drugs and certain foodstuff. She started this business in 2002 located in front of her house in the Hédzranawoé district in Lomé. This business enables her to do her financial share in managing the household. Thanks to her accommodating qualities, she manages to earn the loyalty of her customers. She has approached WAGES to buy certain generic pharmaceuticals that are lacking, as well as some food items. She is quite confident about repaying the loan per the required payment schedule.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic pharmaceuticals, canned tomatoes, macaroni, and various other goods

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida M. is from the village of Hinaplanon, Iligan City. She is 47 years old. Leonida is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonida owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products in the local community. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Leonida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest to expand the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice T. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at her home and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.  Joice is 48 years old and is widowed, with five children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda S. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Merlinda is widowed and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlinda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Merlinda has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Merlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlinda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Merlinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina D. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 37 years old. Gina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business selling ready-to-wear items to local community members. Gina also runs a food vending business. 

Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to meet the needs of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et est mère de 02 enfants ; elle exerce comme activité la vente en détail de sacs dames et de certains produits de beauté dans le quartier de Bè Kpota à Lomé. Elle exerce ce commerce de manière ambulante et arrive à fidéliser ses clientes grâce à ses qualités de marketing et d’approche client. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 2002 et arrive à apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Elle s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé auprès des boutiques chinoises. Elle sollicite urgemment un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des sacs de sortie de différentes catégories et certains produits de beauté.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of two children. She has a retail business selling women’s bags and certain beauty products in the Bè Kpota district in Lomé. She operates by going door-to-door and manages to win the loyalty of her customers, thanks to her customer-oriented marketing skills. She started this business in 2002 and manages to do her financial share in managing the household. She stocks up at the Grand Marketplace of Lomé from Chinese shops. She’s urgently requesting a WAGES loan to buy handbags of different kinds and certain beauty products.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy women's bags and beauty products

loans.name: Malou

texts.en:
Malou R. is from the village of Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 26 years old. Malou is single and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Malou owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Malou has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Malou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Malou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Malou is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Malou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product range.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia T. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. Virginia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en:
Agapita G., 54, lives in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City with her husband Romeo, 53, a carpenter, and their three children.  

Agapita makes rags sewn from fabric trimmings that she buys from garment factories. She then sells the finished rags to customers. Agapita earns at least P3,000.00 a month.  

She needs a new loan in the amount of P8,000.00 so she can buy more scrap fabrics for her business. She hopes to make her workshop a lot bigger in the future so that she can be of help to many unemployed individuals.     

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy fabric trimmings.

loans.name: Yaovi Julien

texts.fr: Cet homme a ouvert dans le quartier de Bè à Lomé une boutique de vente de boissons locales alcoolisées dénommées « sodabi » ; cette boisson est très appréciée de la population pour sa qualité. Il vend également du vin rouge, des liqueurs étrangères mais aussi des produits de toilettes et de lessive. Cette activité lui permet surtout de se prendre en charge et de subvenir aux besoins de sa femme et de ses 02 enfants. Il a débuté ce commerce depuis 2007 et a su fidéliser sa clientèle. Il a besoins d’approvisionner en boissons et autres liqueurs, ainsi qu’en savons de toilettes ; c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES.
texts.en:
This is a man who opened a shop in his district of Bè in Lomé selling a local alcoholic drink named "sodabi". People appreciate it a lot for its quality. He also sells red wine, foreign liquers, and also bath and laundry products. This business enables him in particular to support himself and to provide for his wife and his two children. He started this business in 2007 and figured out how to win the loyalty of his customers. He has a need to stock up on drinks and other liquers, as well as bath soaps. For these reasons, he's requesting a WAGES loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an alcoholic drink, wines, and liqueurs

loans.name: Toun

texts.en: Toun S., 56, is married with three children. He resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with his wife and children. To make a living, he is employed as a construction builder in his province, earning an income of US $3 per day. The family is assisted mainly by his three children, who are construction builders like his father in the city, earning collectively an income of US $3 each per day to help cover the household expenses. Mr. S. and his family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. By doing so, he hopes that his family is able to cut back on public transportation expense and save more money for the future.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Oping

texts.en: Oping I. is from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. She is 52 years old, is married, and has eight school-aged children. Oping owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling fruit in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Oping joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Pheany Nget Group

texts.en: Mrs. Pheany N. is a group leader of six, who all live in Daom village in Takeo province. She breeds pigs, and is also a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She faces an obstacle because her field is infertile which is badly affecting her crop. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field and make the crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Srey Sarun, is a teacher in the local school. Mrs. Pheany N. is 42 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the field and make the crops more productive.

loans.name: Omari

texts.en: Omari D. is a Tanzanian businessman. He is married and has two children. He runs a clothing store at Buguruni district in Dar es Salaam. He also runs a kindergarten school at Buguruni with thirty school children. He purchases both new and used clothes from both wholesale and retail stores. He has been in the business for four years and has managed to buy a plot for house construction at Dar es Salaam. He is requesting a loan of T.shs 600,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To expand the business.

loans.name: Night

texts.en:
Night S. is currently in the business of selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more materials to use. Night is 28 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to use.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita G. is a vendor of fruits and vegetables in their village, and her weekly net income is PHP 750.00. She sells her fruits and vegetables every day house to house. She wants to acquire more income in order to maintain her business and to make it more productive. She is requesting a loan amount of PHP 5,000. She plans to have a retail store of fruits and vegetables when she earns enough money.

Their family resides at the village of Magdalena, Cauayan City, Isabela, a rural area. She has two children, and they both study in the same school at Magdalena Elementary School. Teresita wants her children to finish their studies and to have a good education in order to have a better future.

loans.use: Additional capital for her fruits and vegetables business.

loans.name: Ayikoevi

texts.fr: Cet homme vend des produits d’un genre particulier : il vend des produits cosmétiques destinés aux dames, alors que cette activité est normalement réservée aux femmes. Il a débuté ce commerce en 2007 à Lomé. Il s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé mais aussi au Ghana. Ses clientes trouvent dans sa boutique tout ce dont elles ont besoins. Elles apprécient beaucoup la qualité de son accueil et la façon dont il répond à leurs attentes. Il voudrait en ce moment renouveler son stock en baisse ; c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des articles manquants. Il est marié et a à sa charge 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This is a man who sells a particular type of product: he sells cosmetics for women to use, although this business is normally reserved for women. He started it in 2006 in Lomé. He stocks up at the Grand Marketplace of Lomé and also in Ghana. His customers find everything they need in his shop. They appreciate very much how accommodating he is and the way he responds to their expectations. At this time, he would like to renew his dwindling stock. This is why he's requesting a WAGES loan, so as to purchase the products he lacks. He is married and has two children to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Len

texts.en: Len D., 26, is single. She resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with her parents. To make a living, she is engaged in the business of selling various kinds of groceries, earning an income of US $5 per day. This is the  primary source of income for the family and helps cover the family's expenses. D. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. Therefore, D. is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase more groceries to stock her store in order to expand her current business. She hopes to be able to invest her future profits in her business, which will then generate a better income and enable her to save more money for the future.

loans.use: To buy more groceries.

loans.name: Kim Huon

texts.en: Mr. Kim Huon C. is a villager in Ampil Lech village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns 3 hectares of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Haem Sary, breeds pigs. Now she wants to expand her pig breeding business, so Mr. Kim Huon C. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets more, pig feed, and to build a piggery for breeding. He is 59 years old and the father of five children, two of whom are workers while the others are enrolled in the local school. His wife is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets, pig feed, and to build a piggery for breeding.

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.en:
Gregorio T. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. He is 43 years old. Gregorio is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Gregorio owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing recycling services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from hauling plastics and other recyclables for local community members.

Gregorio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gregorio is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gregorio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of his family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Rochelle

texts.en:
Rochelle A. is from the village of Palao, Iligan City. She is 30 years old. Rochelle is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rochelle makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Rochelle has been in business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rochelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rochelle is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rochelle from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng S., 53, is married with three school-aged children. He resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with his wife and children. To make a living, he operates his motorbike as a taxi driver everywhere in the town, earning an income of $5 per day. The family is assisted mainly by his wife, who is engaged in a business of selling sugar cane juice, earning collectively an income of $8 per day as a primary source of income for the family to help cover the household expenses. 

Mr. S. and his family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. Therefore, he is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a new motorbike to improve his current business. His old motorbike is unreliable and is often in need of repair, so he has decided that he wants to replace it.

loans.use: Buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en:
Nhor C. lives in Krang Touch village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice. His wife, Suth Phun, is a duck breeder. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it. 

Nhor C. decided to ask for a loan to buy 1,500 ducklings for breeding. He hopes to increase their income and improve the family's standard of living with this loan. He is 38 years old and the father of five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending to local school. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy ducklings for breeding

loans.name: Gorgonia

texts.en:
Gorgonia C. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Gorgonia is married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Gorgonia owns & operates a specialized retail store selling personal products such as glasses and kids watches and others in the local community. Gorgonia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gorgonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gorgonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Gorgonia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gorgonia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Esso-Simna

texts.fr: Cette femme est spécialisée dans la vente d’huile végétale de très bonne qualité dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière à son mari carreleur dans l’éducation de leurs 03 enfants. Elle s’approvisionne à Vogan et à Tsévié, deux villes situées à des dizaines de kilomètres de Lomé. Elle parvient à écouler sa marchandise dans un délai très court à cause de la qualité de ses huiles. Elle vend aussi bien en gros qu’en détail. En ce moment elle voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour commander 25 bidons d’huile végétale.
texts.en:
This woman is specialized in selling very high quality vegetable oil in the Hédzranawoé district in Lomé. This business enables her to do her financial share for her husband, who is a tile mason, to educated their three children. She stocks up in Vogan and in Tsévié, two cities located dozens of kilometers from Lomé. She manages to turn over her merchandise after a very short interval because of the quality of her oils. She also sells wholesale more so than retail. At this time, she would like to obtain a WAGES loan to order 25 containers of vegetable oil.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetable oil

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov C. lives in Trapaing Tnaut village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who cultivates rice on a piece of land she owns. Her husband, Mr. Kak Pann, is a construction worker. This couple has two children, one of whom is a security guard in a garment factory and the other is attending the local school. Since their first child’s work place is far from their home, they face an obstacle because they usually pay for the motorbike taxi fare. Thus, Mrs. Pov C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her first child to drive to work. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her first child to drive to work.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence O., 32, has operated a butchery for three plus years.  He previously worked for a butcher and he currently has two branches of the Upendo Butchery.  He offers only beef products and has one employee in his Nyalenda operation.  He services households and hotels, and his next business goal is to get refrigeration for the Nyalenda stall.  He is using this loan to increase his meat offerings and he would eventually like to own a slaughterhouse and supply small butcheries.  He is married and his wife sells fish in another kiosk.  They have three small children and their dream is to educate them.

loans.use: To increase his volume -- from 20Kgs meat per day to 50Kgs

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma D. is from the village of Highway Lawis. She is 58 years old. Alma is married and has 4 school-aged children. Alma makes & sells household furniture to local businesses and community members. Alma has been in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (about $172 US) a month for these activities.

In 2003, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 pesos from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Alma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Alma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For inventory and working capital

loans.name: Ayabavi

texts.fr: Cette femme vend depuis 1995 des pagnes de qualité dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé ; cette longue expérience lui a permis de disposer d’un grand réseau de fournisseurs et de clients. Elle vend parfois à des clientes sur commande, à domicile. Elle vend aussi des sacs de sortie pour dames ainsi que des marmites traditionnelles. Elle est très passionnée pour ce commerce qui lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière à son mari pour l’éducation de leur unique enfant. Elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES  pour acheter 15 pagnes Hitarget, 15 pagnes Wax Hollandais ainsi que certains sacs de sortie pour dames.
texts.en:
This woman has been selling high quality textiles since 1995 in the Hedzranawoe market in Lome. Her long experience grants her the benefits of a large network of suppliers and clients. Sometimes she sells on demand and delivers to private homes. She also sells ladies' handbags and traditional pots. She is very devoted to this business and it allows her to bring a financial contribution to her husband for the education of their only child. She requests a loan from Wages (Kiva Field Partner) to purchase 15 measures of Hitarget fabric, 15 measures of Wax Hollandais and a selection of ladies' handbags.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase textiles and ladies' handbags

loans.name: Nat

texts.en:
Mrs. Nat K. is a villager in Prey Preal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Khoem Naev, is a cow middleman. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it by purchasing two more cows to resell to earn more income. Thus, Mrs. Nat K. decided to request for a loan for this purpose.

Mrs. Nat K. is 37 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school and the other is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two more cows for her husband's business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to buy more items such as cassava, beans, maize etc to sell.  Esther is 30 years old and is married to a carpenter. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house for renting.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Raphaèl

texts.fr: F. Raphaèl est née le 23 Mars 1971 et vit depuis 18 ans dans le quartier Sainte Cécile à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Marié à EZOUN Eliane, une revendeuse, Raphaèl est père de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. En plus de ces enfants, Raphaèl a deux autres enfants en charge. Raphaèl vit ensemble avec ses enfants et supporte les charges de la famille. Raphaèl a arrêté l’école au cours primaire. Pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille, Raphaèl vend depuis 5 ans déjà, des boissons (bières et sucreries) dans son quartier à Sainte Cécile. Raphaèl fait ses approvisionnements aux dépôts des boissons à Cotonou. C’est un ancien client de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’agrandir son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Raphaèl sollicite un nouveau crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Raphael F. was born on March 23, 1971 and for the past 18 years he has lived in the Sainte Cecile district in Cotonou, the capital city of Benin. He is married to Eliane Ezoun, a resaler. Raphael is the father of four children, all of whom are attending school. In addition to his own children, Raphael has two other children in his care. Raphael lives together with his children and provides for the family's needs. Raphael stopped attending primary school. In order to provide for his family, for the past 5 years Raphael has been selling drinks (beers and soft-drinks) in their home district of Sainte Cecile. Raphael purchases his supplies in the beverage depots in Cotonou. He is member of Alide and he has had loans in the past that have been completely repaid. In order to expand his business and to meet his clients' demands, Raphael is requesting a new loan from Alide.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cases of beer and canned soft-drinks.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz C. is a 54-year-old mother of two, the eldest of which is already working and the other is still in grade school.  Her husband Eduardo, 51, is a family driver.  They live in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.

Beatriz owns a general store located in their house.  She is also into the popular direct selling of cosmetic products and apparel offered by prominent brands (Personal Collection, Avon, Sarah Lee, etc.).    She also sells electronic load credits for mobile phones.  With all these combined, she earns at least P8,000.00 a month.
 
She is now on her 14th loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She applied for a P35,000.00 loan with the cooperative to purchase more cosmetic products for her clients.  She will also use portions of the fund as additional capital for her store.  

Beatriz hopes to establish her own cosmetics outlet soon.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for cosmetics and general store

loans.name: Ludah

texts.en:
Ludah S. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 34 years old. Ludah is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ludah owns & operates a specialized retail store selling personal use products such as cosmetics and body spray in the local community. Ludah has been engaged in her business for over  years and earns approximately 3930 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ludah joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ludah is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ludah from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith A. is from the village of Bobontugan, Jasaan Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old. Judith is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Judith owns & operates a business selling a variety of daily use products in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Judith is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Judith from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hold Sorbeh Group

texts.en:
Meet Members of the Hold Sorbeh Group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city who have come to SMT/Kiva to seek their very first loan. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 for each to enable them expand their businesses.

Fatmata M. (right) is the leader of this group. Fatmata was born in Lunsar, a small town in northern Sierra Leone. She is thirty years old. She is married to a businessman and they have three children. Two of Fatmata’s children are attending primary school – one is in class IV, the other is in class V and the last is not of school-going age.  Fatmata sells “rice cakes” (bread made from rice) and has been in this business for four years now. Fatmata will use her share of the loan to buy rice, oil and other ingredients to make more rice-cakes.

loans.use: Purchase supplies to make more rice-cakes to sell

loans.name: Mawuena

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de chaussures pour dames et enfants dans le marché de Hédzranawoé. Elle est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants. Cette activité lui permet d’aider financièrement son  mari dans la gestion du foyer. Elle s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé auprès de plusieurs fournisseurs. Elle dispose d’une clientèle assez vaste qui lui permet de vite écouler sa marchandise. En ce moment elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commander 05 cartons de chaussures pour dames, 10 cartons de chaussures pour enfants.
texts.en:
This woman's source of revenues is the sale of ladies' and children's shoes in the Hedzranawoe market. She is married and she is the mother of 3 children. Her business allows her to help her husband financially with the household expenses. She purchases her products from various suppliers in Grand Marche in Lome. She counts on a client-base large enough that she can sell-out her merchandise very quickly. Currently she is requestin a loan from Wages (Kiva Field Partner) in order to purchase 5 boxes of ladies' shoes and 10 boxes of chidren's shoes.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes.

loans.name: Kalomp Group

texts.en:
Above are members of the Kalomp group.  They are small scale entrepreneurs who want a loan of Le 1,500,000 to enable them to improve their businesses. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, sales will improve and so will their sales-to-profit-margin. With a larger profit at their disposal, they will be able to better look after themselves and their children.  

Zainab B. (left) is the leader of this group.  Zainab was born in Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. She is now 35 and married to a carpenter. They have four children. All of Zainab’s children attend primary school. Zainab owns a small shop where she sells items like cold drinks, sardines, peak-milks, biscuits and breads. She has been a businesswoman for more than ten years now. Zainab will use her loan to buy more drinks, sardines, peak-milks and biscuits to add to her shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory items for her shop

loans.name: Toch

texts.en: Toch L., 54, is married with three children and resides in Phnom Penh City with her husband. To make a living, she sells food and rents parts of her house, earning an income of US $11 per day as a primary source of income for the family to help cover the household expenses. Also, her husband helps his wife with the current business. The family is partly assisted by one of her children who is an accountant for a private company. L. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. Therefore, L. is asking for a loan of US $500 to expand the current business by selling more types of food to her new and existing customers. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To expand the food selling business

loans.name: Lane Kuru Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Lane Kuru group (Lane Kuru is Temne, meaning Believe in God). They are small-scale businesspeople in the northern City of Makeni. The members of Lane Kuru have already taken out several loans from SMT/Kiva.  With the help of previous SMT/Kiva loans, these entrepreneurs have been able to expand their businesses and improve their standard of living. To further increase their businesses, they are again requesting a new of SLL 800,000 for each. 

The leader of this group is Mohamed K. in the middle.  Mohamed was born in a place call Yenkisa, in northern Sierra Leone. He is approximately age 55, married to a businesswoman and they have seven children. One of his children is in college and the rest are attending both primary and secondary schools. Mohamed sells local produce like groundnuts/peanuts, kola-nuts, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) and many more. Mohamed has been a businessman since childhood days. Mohamed will invest this loan into his business by buying more goods -- ground-nuts, kola-nuts and palm-oil to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory items to expand the stock in his stall

loans.name: Abra-Hemefa

texts.fr: Cette femme est une expérimentée dans le commerce de pagne au Togo ; en effet elle a derrière elle plus de 30 ans d’expérience, parce qu’elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 1977 à Lomé. Actuellement elle vend ses pagnes dans le Marché de Hédzranawoé et de ses environs à Lomé. Elle est connue de beaucoup de clientes âgées qui constituent la majorité de sa clientèle. Elle s’approvisionne aussi bien dans le Grand Marché de Lomé et se rend aussi en Côte d’Ivoire pour acheter certains pagnes de qualités appréciés par les jeunes dames. Elle voudrait disposer de crédit de WAGES pour acheter certains de ses pagnes en baisse en ce moment ; le reste du prêt couvrira les frais de transport. Elle est mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman is an experienced merchant of textiles in Togo, with more than 30 years of experience behind her. She started her business in Lome in 1977. Currently she sells textiles in the Hedzranawoe market and in the neighboring regions of Lome. She knows many seniors and they make up the majority of her clientele. She makes her purchases reaonsably well in the Grand Marche market in Lome but she also goes to Ivory Coast to purchase certain textlies appealing to younger ladies. She would like to use the loan from Wages (Kiva Field Partner) to purchase some textiles that are currently conveniently priced, and the rest of the fund swill be used to cover the transportation expenses. She is the mother of 2 children.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase textiles.

loans.name: Member Good Group

texts.en:
The people you see here make up the Member Good group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs who do business in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan to further strengthen their businesses. These entrepreneurs have received previous SMT/Kiva loans, for which they have thanked God because those loans have helped them feed their families, pay school fees and medical bills and more. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are requesting a new loan to further improve their businesses.

Aminata S. (seen here in the middle) is the leader of the group. She was born in Robuya Romende, in northern Sierra Leone, and is 34 years old, married and has three children. Her husband is a police officer. Two of their children are in primary school, while the third is not yet of school-going age. Aminata sells ready-to-wear-clothes for children, and has been in this business for 19 years .

loans.use: To further strengthen and improve several small businesses

loans.name: Krestyna

texts.en:
This is Krestyna M., a young businesswoman who lives in a poor community in Tala, Caloocan City with her husband and two children.  She is one of the newest members of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, and runs a small food stall where she cooks and sells different items. Most of her customers are students and drivers. She earns at least P3,000 a month, which helps her meet her daily basic needs. She has applied for a loan to buy ingredients to cook more of the food she makes and sells.  Krestyna dreams of having her own a restaurant.  

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian to against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  
CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients needed to cook the items she sells to her customers

loans.name: On Time Traders Group

texts.en:
This is the On-Time Traders Group. They are small-scale businesspeople who live and work in the northern city of Makeni. They have come to SMT for the first time for a loan of Le 500,000 so that they can expand their businesses. This loan will allow them to buy more items to sell, generate more sales and earn more profits. This will, in turn, mean a better standard of living, including more clothing, food and education for their children. 

Adama Fornah (left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Matotoka village, about eight miles from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. She is now about 45 years old and is married to a businessman. They have five children – one in secondary school, one in primary school and the others not yet old enough to attend classes. She makes a living selling cakes, rice and groundnuts, and has been in this line of work for many years.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies that can be made into cakes and snacks to sell

loans.name: Thai

texts.en: Thai K., 26, is single and lives in Phnom Penh City with his parents. He makes a living as an interpreter and also rents parts of his house to workers who are employed in a nearby garment factory. He is the main source of income for his family, earning $9 per day to help cover expenses. K. and his family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. That is why he has applied for a loan of US $650 to repair his house. By doing so, he hopes to give his renters better living conditions. This is his first loan from Kiva partner CREDIT.

loans.use: to repair his house

loans.name: Tamuyu Group

texts.en:
Here are the members of the Tamuyu group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makeni city. Business has been growing at a very slow pace for these entrepreneurs because they lack capital. That is why they have applied to SMT/Kiva for a loan of Le 500,000 to help expand their businesses.

Abdul K. (left) is the leader of this group. He was born in Makeni, is 29 years old and married to a  businesswoman. They have one child who is not yet of school age. Abdul makes a living selling items such as mints, biscuits, batteries, candles and soap. He has been a businessman since his childhood days.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies of soap, batteries, biscuits, and other items to sell at a busy location

loans.name: B. Ingrid

texts.fr: Z. B. Ingrid est née en 1976 et vit depuis vingt ans à Sainte Cécile à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ATCHEFON Ahlonsou, un pêcheur, Ingrid est mère de trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par le conjoint seul. Ingrid n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis une quinzaine d'année, Ingrid vend des poissons frais dans son quartier à Sainte Cécile. Ingrid fait ses approvisionnements à la poissonnerie à Cotonou. Ingrid est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Pour renforcer son activité et agrandir sa clientèle, Ingrid sollicite un nouveau crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
B. Ingrid Z. was born in 1976 and for the past twenty years she has lived in Sainte Cecile in Cotonou, the capital region of Benin. She is married to Ahlonsou Atchefon, a fisherman. Ingrid is the mother of three children, some of whom are attending school. The family's expenses are taken care of by her partner. Ingrid has never attended school. For the past fifteen years Ingrid has been selling fresh fish in Sainte Cecile. Ingrid purchases her products in the fish market of Cotonou. Ingrid is a long-time member of Alide (Kiva Field Partner) and she always repaid her loans. In order to support her business and to increase her clientele, Ingrid is requesting a loan from Alide.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cartons of fish.

loans.name: Sarafina

texts.en: Sarafina A. is currently in the business of selling fresh fish and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase other items such as dried fish, beef, and more tomatoes to sell. Sarafina is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has three children who all attend school. If she is able to make extra profits as a result of using this loan for her business, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase dried fish, beef, and more tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard D. is pastor and runs a small stand in the Bandani Market selling food products.  His business is called the Brenda Shop and he has run it for five years.  He has one employee and caters to local households and walk-in customers.

Richard's main business challenge is accessing working capital to increase his inventory.  He plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to buy more maize, flour, soap, etc. for the stand. His primary business goal is to have a bigger shop with more stock.

Richard is married with seven children.  His youngest child is a two-year-old named Barack and his oldest is a 17-year-old named Lucas.  Richard is a priest in a local church (he is pictured with his vestments on) and he describes himself as a man of the people.  His dream is to educate his children for a better future.

loans.use: To buy maize, flour, soap, salad, and bread for a small food store.

loans.name: Tamemsu Group

texts.en:
This is Mabinty K., Aminata K. and Adamsay B.. They named their group Tamemsu, a Temne phrase meaning “Give us a Try”. They are small scale businesswomen in Makeni city who want a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leones each to enable them expand their businesses. This will be their very first loan from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that they can attract more customers, make better sales, earn more profit and improve on their living standard. 

Mabinty K. (in the middle) is the leader of the group. Mabinty is now age forty-four and was born in a place call Sanda, near Makeni City (in northern Sierra Leone).  She is a widow, with five children. Four of her children are adults and one is in Junior Secondary School II. Mabinty sells firewood, cooked rice and market food (such as onions, tomatoes, fish, and spices). She has been in this business for well over thirty years now.

loans.use: To buy firewood, rice, and other staples for resale

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema K. is a Tanzanian businesswoman. She is married and has three children. One is in primary school and two are in secondary school. She runs two businesses, one where she sells charcoal, and the other where she makes bricks.  She sells both goods at Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the charcoal wholesale from the suppliers and sells it retail to customers.  At her brick business, she employs 2 workers. She buys the manufacturing materials from the hardware wholesale shops. She has been in business for four years and with the business revenue, she is able to pay her children's school fees. She needs a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to expand both businesses.

loans.use: To expand charcoal sales and brick manufacturing businesses

loans.name: Alili

texts.en:
This is Alili M., a young entrepreneur from Tala, Caloocan City.  She is 31 years old.  Her husband works for a bus company.  They have two children living with them. 

Alili weaves foot-rugs by hand out of scrap fabric.  She also makes home-made sausages and sells them to her neighbors.  She makes a net income of at least 3,000 Philippine pesos (about $64 US) a month from these businesses which she has been enjoying doing for years.  

Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative early this year, Alili has been enjoying its many benefits for its members who are mostly housewives.  She is now on her 3rd loan cycle with CCT.  She is expecting to receive a fresh loan of 8,000 pesos from the cooperative which she will use to purchase scrap fabric from nearby garment factories as raw material for her trendy foot-rugs.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase scrap fabric for rug making

loans.name: Tabome

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme est un célibataire et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Il exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente des produits d’alimentation générale dans sa boutique située dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Il vend tous les produits permettant d’alimenter les gens de voisinage, qui n’ont plus besoin parfois de se rendre au marché pour leurs besoins d’urgence. Elle a de bonnes dispositions lui permettant de bien accueillir ses clients. En ce moment il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 cartons de tomates en boîtes, 05 cartons d’eau Minérale Awa et bien d’autres produits indispensables à son commerce.
texts.en:
This young man is single and he does not children in his care. His revenues come from the sale of general food products in a store located in Hedzranawoe in Lome. He sells all kinds of food products for the people in the neighborhood, not being forced to go to the market to for something they need right away. He is attentive to people which allows him to attract his clients. He is requesting a loan of Wages (Kiva Field Partner) in order to purchase 10 boxes of tomatoes, 5 crates of bottled water of the Mineral Awa brand and other indespensable products for his business.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase general food products.

loans.name: Mohira

texts.ru: Мохира Курбонова проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 40 лет. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Муж работает в местной налоговой инспекции. Сама Мохира более 15 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном торгует одеждой. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота, закупа нового ассортимента.
texts.en:
