loans.use: To buy meat to sell, to expand his business.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is a 33-year-old married woman with four children aged between 9 and 17 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she lives with six people. She also takes care of additional family members. The Family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and medication.

Zaituni works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She uses public transport to and from shopping and incurs transport costs to and from buying fruits and vegetables from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of twenty-five customers a day and sells to all categories of people but retail only. Her major business challenges include the ever increasing prices of fruits and vegetables and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her because she works in a open place.

Zaituni has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for seven years and is servicing her twentieth loan. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of fruits and vegetables like mangoes, oranges, tomatoes and cabbages. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: God Time Is The Best Group

texts.en:
Eric W. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called “God time is the best”. He is 28 years old and is a single youth who is a high school graduate presently studying electronics at the Monrovia Vocational Training Center in Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. Eric lives and work on the Kebbah Road, Barnerville, north of Monrovia.

Eric’s business is the sale of GSM companies’ cellphone recharge cards, money exchange and the sale of petroleum (gasoline) by the gallon to residents of Kebbah. He started his business with $200 that was given to him by his sister. He has been running this business for four years and is hoping to improve to the importation of consumer goods into Liberia in the future.

Eric talks to customers with a good manner in order to encourage them to continue promoting his business. His difficulties are when distributors delay with recharge cards and the scarcity of petroleum in the country. 

Eric needs this loan to purchase more recharge cards, petroleum and as add-up cash to use for his money-exchange to improve business. He dreams of giving his family a better education so as to prepare them for their future ahead.

loans.use: To purchase more recharge cards, petroleum and to use as add-up cash for money exchange

loans.name: Saobaddin

texts.en:
K. Saobaddin is 40 years old. He is married and has three children. He has successful business selling flour at the local market in Isfara. Saobaddin sells an assortment of good quality flour. Because he buys the flour wholesale, his price is cheaper than the price of his competitors. Thus, he has many customers, some of whom even buy flour straight from his house. Today he has a great demand for his goods and that is why he wants to take an individual loan. Saobaddin has requested a loan of $1100 USD to add to his working capital and allow him to purchase more inventory. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once and a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy flour to sell

loans.name: Kamu Kamu Group Of Lugazi

texts.en:
Emma N. is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hard-working, determined, married woman who has three children, ages 12, 11 and 10 years old. She also cares for her parents. Emma has been selling firewood in central Lugazi for one year. Before this business, she operated a bar. She is able to make 150,000/= Ugandan shillings in profit each week. This enables her to care for her family and expand her business. 

She is grateful for her loans because they have ensured quality in her business and made it possible for her to increase her stock. In the future, Emma hopes to become a wholesaler of firewood; supplying to schools, hospitals, barracks and colleges. She also wants to educate her children and build a house for them. 

She needs a loan to help re-capitalize her business and provide a steady supply of products to her customers. This is Emma’s 69th loan with her group.

loans.use: To buy firewood to resell

loans.name: Help Yourself Group

texts.en:
Ballah K. is a leader of a five-member loan group called "Help Yourself." He is 40 years old and married. He has 5 children, ages 8-20 years old, whose educational levels range from  kindergarten to 8th grade. Ballah dropped out of school in 6th grade due to poverty. He and his family live and work on the Kebbah Road in Barnersville, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Ballah has a general store.He buys consumer goods, such as body cream, bath soaps,batteries, and food, in wholesale quantities and sells then retail from a table to the residents of Kebbah, Barnersville, Monrovia, Liberia. He has been running this business for 10 years and hopes to improve it in the future by importing consumer goods into Liberia .

To encourage customer to continue to patronize his business, Ballah talks to customers in politely and never gets angry when customers misbehave. He started his business with LD$150.00 from his savings and money from selling charcoal.  He needs this loan to purchase more consumer goods to improve his  business. Ballah dreams of providing a better education for his children and building a house for them in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for his general store

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Khady S. est une femme de 49 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO depuis 7 ans et demi. Avec son prêt elle développe un commerce de bananes, elle achète en gros par régimes et revend au détaille en faisant du porte à porte. Ses bénéfices lui servent à participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.
texts.en:
Khady S., aged 49, is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the village bank Kandé Banéto for seven and a half years. She uses her loan to develop her banana business. She buys bunches of bananas wholesale and resells them hawking from house to house. The profit enables her to participate in the improvement of her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her fruit business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria J. sells bread and tea in a resturant. She is requesting a loan to purchase other items, such as sugar, soap, and cooking oil to sell. Victoria is 28 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy different type of items to sell

loans.name: Sabina Wanjiku

texts.en:
Sabina Wanjiku is 57 years old and the mother of two children. She is married to John Mkono. Her primary business is dairy farming. She supplies milk in the Uthiru Shopping Center and its area. She also owns rental houses. She has been in the dairy farming business for about 20 years and earns a profit of about 15000 Kenya shillings a month.

Wanjiku has never borrowed from any other financial institution, but this will be her fifth loan from KADET. She was introduced in KADET by the KADET staff. She wants to use her loan to buy another dairy cow so she can provide more milk to meet her client's demands. She hopes to have more cows and supply more milk to dairy cooperative societies. She also hopes to add more rental houses in order to improve her living standard.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow for her dairy business

loans.name: Mzungu

texts.en: Mr. M. is a 27-year-old single gentleman who resides in the Mishomoroni area.He is currently servicing his first loan at KADET, Ltd. Mr. M. conducts his business at the Kongowea Market in Mombasa. He sells spices and he also does some repairs. He was introduced to KADET, Ltd. by existing clients. He plans to expand his business into a large establishment by selling his products throughout the Kongowea Market. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To increase his supply of spices and udongo (sand for building houses) for his repairs

loans.name: God's Blessing Group

texts.en:
Oretha D. the leader of a five-member loan group called "God’s Blessings." She is 37 years old and married. She has six children, ages 4 months to 21 years old. Their educational levels range from kindergarten to 9th grade. Oretha also cares for three in-laws. She is an illiterate due to poverty.

Oretha and her family lives and work in the dry rice market community in Barnesville, which is north of Monrovia, the capital of  Liberia. The market sells only ingredients for a local dish called dry rice. 

Oretha sells charcoal and raw rice. She buys the charcoal and rice wholesale and sells it retails from a table to the residents of the Barnesville dry rice market community near Monrovia, Liberia. She has been running this business for 22 years and hopes to improve her shop.

To encourage customers to continue patronizing her business, Oretha sells clean and high-quality rice at an affordable price. She started her business with LD$150.00 of her savings from selling peanuts and seasoning materials. She needs this loan to purchase more charcoal and rice to improve her business. Oretha dreams of giving her children a better education and building a house for them in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and rice

loans.name: Abomukisa's Group

texts.en:
Abomukisa S. is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a jolly, hard working, and friendly man. He is married and has 11 children, ages 18  to 35. Six of his children are still in school. In addition, he cares for his siblings. 

S. is a tailor in Lugazi. He also has been selling cosmetics for children, ladies and men for 7 years. Before that, he was a driver, and then he moved on to manage his own businesses. He does not regret the change, because he is able to make good profits from his business. He is grateful for his loans because they have helped him move on, and have recapitalized his businesses so he can earn more profits. He hopes to be able to save enough so that he does not need loans during his very old age. 

He needs a loan to buy more tailoring materials and cosmetics, so that he can save enough to pay his children’s school fees next year. This is his loan group's 69th loan.

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials and more cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Casa Mas Group

texts.fr: Nous avions déjà eu un prêt de Kiva que nous avons fini  de rembourser il y a longtemps(50953). Ce pendant au cours de notre exercice, nous avons rencontrer un partenaire européen qui nous a proposé d'ouvrir un restaurant dans une grande ville , où nous pourrons vendre les produits issus de notre écovillage. C'est ainsi que nous sommes venues à Dakar et avons trouvé un bon emplacement qui peut nous servir de restaurant avec une grande capacité d'accueil. ayant trouvé l'endroit idéal, nous venons auprès de vous pour demander le renouvellement de notre prêt pour que nous puissions oeuvrer de façon plus grand et ainsi avoir un emploi durables pour tous les membres de notre groupe. Nous sommes vraiment très confiantes dans l'avenir grâce à la première expérience que nous avons eu avec le premier prêt. Maintenant, ce deuxième prêt va nous servir à élargir notre champs d'action, car le premier nous a servi à monter un petit restaurant dans le village et que maintenant que nous avons un peu d'expérience, nous voulons exploiter d'une façon plus importante  notre capacité à travailler.
texts.en:
We had already a Kiva loan that we have paid off long ago. However, during our activity, we met a European partner who proposed us to open a restaurant in a large city, in which we could sell the products from our ecovillage. Thus we came to Dakar and found a good location, where we can open a restaurant with a large seat capacity. Now that we have found the perfect location, we come to you and apply for the renewal of our loan. It will enable us to work on a larger scale and secure sustainable employment for each member of our group. We are very confident in our future, thanks to the experience we gained with our first loan. This second loan will help us to broaden our scope, as the first loan was used to open just a small restaurant, but now we will use our gained experience to operate on a larger scale and fully exploit our working capacity.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To equip our new restaurant

loans.name: Siring

texts.fr: Siring MANE est une femme de 53 ans elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants dont elle a la charge. Depuis son adhésion au Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO le 18 août 2005, elle ne cesse de faire des performances remarquables. Elle est vendeuse de bananes, ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son activité afin de générer des bénéficies pour faire face aux différentes besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Siring Mané, aged 53, is married and the mother of four children whom she supports. Since she joined the village bank Kandé Banéto on August 18, 2005, she didn't stop improving her situation remarkably. She is a trader selling bananas. This loan will enable her to bolster her business and generate sufficient profit to meet the various needs of her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her fruit trade

loans.name: His Grace Group

texts.en:
Marie H. is the leader of a five-member loan group called "His Grace." She is 50 years old and married. She has five children, ages 8 to 28 years old. Their educational levels range from 3rd grade to a sophomore college student. She is also responsible for two of her nieces. She is a professional nurse who decided to start a business. Marie and her family live and work in the Barnesville Estate, which is north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Marie sells farina, a local Liberian food that is made from cassava. She also makes soap. She buys the farina and the chemicals to make soap from wholesalers and sell them retail to residents of Barnesville Estate. She has been running this business for 4 years and hopes to improve it by establishing branches around Monrovia.

Marie talks to her customers politely and sells at affordable prices in order to encourage customers to continue patronizing her business. She started her business with LD$160.00 which was given to her by her husband. She needs this loan to purchase more charcoal and chemicals to produce more soap so she can serve her customers. Marie dreams of giving her children better education and helping family members who are in need.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and chemicals for her soap-making business

loans.name: Federico

texts.en:
Federiko M. sells food in a resturant. She is requesting a loan to buy goods, such as bags of salt, sugar, etc to sell. Federiko is 35 years old and is divorced. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, in the future, she hopes to be able to build a good house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy goods, like bags of salt, sugar, etc., to sell

loans.name: Y. Honorine

texts.fr: G. Y. Honorine est née le 06 Avril 1982 et vit au quartier Houénoussou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis près de 27 ans. Honorine est mariée à WHANDENON Rock Serge, un peintre auto, et est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. En plus de ses enfants, Honorine a un autre enfant en charge. Seul le conjoint de Honorine supporte les charges de la famille. Honorine a fréquenté jusqu'au secondaire. Il y a de cela quatre ans que Honorine vend divers articles (sucre, savons, pâtes alimentaires, conserves, papiers hygiéniques, lait, etc.) à son domicile. Honorine vend également de l'eau glacée et de la glace. Honorine fait ses achats à Dantokpa, marché internationale du Bénin. Honorine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié d'un crédit qui a été bien remboursé. En vue de diversifier son activité et d'augmenter la taille de sa clientèle, Honorine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Y. Honorine was born on April 6, 1982 and has been living in the Houénoussou district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for nearly 27 years. She is married to WHANDENON Rock Serge, an automobile painter, and is the mother of three children who are all in school. In addition to her children, Honorine has another child in her care. Her husband is the only one who is covering family expenses. Honorine has a secondary school education. For four years since then, she has been selling various goods (sugar, soaps, pasta, canned food, toilet paper, milk, etc.) out of her home. She also sells ice and ice cream. She supplies herself at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. Honorine is a former ALIDé client who has had a loan before, which she has repaid. With the aim of diversifying her business and expanding her customer base, she’s requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, boxes of pasta, sugar, soaps, water in packets

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine M. lives in Ijevan. She is married and has three daughters, all of whom are married. Her youngest daughter's family lives with her. 

Karine worked as an economist in a building organization until it closed in 1993. Then Karine and her husband rented a space in the Ijevan Central Market and started selling clothing and shoes. For the past 16 years, thanks to her profits, Karine has paid for her daughters’ educations and organized their weddings. A few years ago, with her own income, Karine supplied free sweets -- chocolate, candy, and cakes -- to Ijevan School N4. 

Karine already has received nine loans from Nor Horizon. Now she needs a loan of 400,000 AMD to buy winter clothes to sell. She plans to spend the expected income to expand her business and repair her apartment.

loans.use: To buy winter clothes to sell

loans.name: Taban

texts.en:
Taban S. sells used clothes in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase shoes, belts, etc to sell. Taban is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 2 children who children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land and build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase shoes, belts, etc. to sell

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia sells drinks, loaves of bread, and groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is a focused and hard worker. She is 54 years old and married with seven children. Her husband is a farmer. 

She has been in this business for a long time. She is hoping for a loan of N80,000 to purchase more drinks and loaves of bread to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and loaves of bread to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy sells drinks, groceries, and food to her customers at retail prices. The demand for her drinks is high and, because this is her busy season, she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 32 years old and married with 5 children. Her husband is a commercial motorcycle driver. All of her children are in school, except for the youngest who is still to young to attend. 

She is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase a refrigerator so she can sell cold drinks. She is, indeed, grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Taban

texts.en:
Taban S. sells charcoal from her home. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Taban is 26 years old and is married. Her husband is a primary school teacher. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Souadou

texts.fr: Souadou B. est une femme de 51 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO depuis 07 ans et demi. Son prêt lui permet de développer une activité de vente de poissons séchés. Elle soutien sa famille à partir des bénéfices qu'elle réalise.
texts.en:
Souadou B. is a 51-year-old woman who is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO for 7½ years. Her loan enables her to develop a business selling dried fish. She supports her family with the profits she makes.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To advance her business selling fish

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
Betty M. is a hard-working and devoted lady. She is married and has six children, ages 13 to 35 years old. She also cares for her siblings. 

Betty is a business lady who sells agricultural produce. Although her business faces a lot of competition from other people in the same business, over the years, she has been able to use her loans constructively. As a result, she has quality produce to sell and more income. In the future, she hopes to become a wholesaler and build rental houses. 

Betty needs a loan to buy more produce to sell.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce to sell

loans.name: Women Of Faith Group

texts.en:
Nohn G. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called "Women of Faith." She is 37 years old and married with the children, ages 9 to 16 years old. Their educational levels range from 1st to 8th grade. Nohn also cares for her two brothers–in- law. She dropped out of school in 8th grade due to early childbirth and poverty. She thought it wise to get into business.

Nohn and her family live and work in the Barnesville Estate north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. She sells consumer goods. She buys the goods, such as pepper, bread, and oil from wholesalers and sells them at retail prices sells to the residents of Barnesville Estate. She also makes soap.

She has been running this business for 10 years and hopes to improve her shop. Nohn talks to her customers politely and sometimes extends credit to customers when they don’t have money. This encourages customers to continue patronizing her business. She started selling dry meat from rural Liberia with LD$1500.00, which was given to her by her sister. 

She needs this loan to purchase flour, oil, seasonings, and some sodas for making soap so that she can serve her customers. Nohn dreams of giving her children and other family members a better education.

loans.use: To purchase flour, oil, seasonings, and soda for making soap

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
Bose has a salon where she creates lovely hair styles for her customers. She also sells hair extension and drinks to her customers at retail prices. With her combined businesses, she is able to support her family. This is the busy season for her sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to own a fashion house in the future. She is 31 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is an engineer. 

She is hoping for a loan of N60,000 to purchase more hair extensions and drinks to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Ndèye

texts.fr: Ndèye S. est une femme de 40 ans elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis le 18 janvier 2001. Elle fait du commerce de bananes, elle achète son produit en gros et revend au détail dans son quartier. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ndèye S. is a 40-year-old woman who is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois since January 18, 2001. She does commerce in bananas. She buys her product wholesale and sells at the retail level in her area. Her profits allow her to help improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her business selling bananas

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: A. Célestine est née en 1967 et réside au quartier Sètovi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis neuf ans. Célestine est mariée à AKPOLI Moïse, un revendeur. Le couple a quatre enfants en charge, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Seul le conjoint supporte les charges de la famille. Célestine n'a jamais fréquenté. Il y a de cela sept ans que Célestine mène comme activité la vente de divers articles (pâtes alimentaires, savons, conserves, lait, mayonnaise, haricot, maïs, farine de manioc, piles, huile végétale, etc.)à son domicile. Célestine s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Célestine a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit de ALIdé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. En vue d'augmenter son capital et de renforcer son étalage, Célestine sollicite un deuxième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Célestine was born in 1967 and has been residing in the Sètovi district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for nine years. She is married to AKPOLI Moïse, a retailer. The couple has four children in school to support. Three of the children are theirs. The husband is the only one covering family expenses. Célestine has never attended school. For seven years since then, she has been running a business selling a variety of goods (pasta, soaps, canned foods, milk mayonnaise, beans, corn, cassava flour, batteries, vegetable oil, etc.) out of her home. She stocks up at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. She has had an ALIDé loan before, which she has repaid. With the aim of increasing her capital and bolstering her display of goods, she’s requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of bean, corn, cassava flour, pasta

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ab

texts.en:
AB makes cellophane and sells it at wholesale and retail prices to her customers. She is a 52-year-old widow with five children. All of her children are excelling in their schoolwork and this gives her joy. She cares for her children alone and she has to work long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed herself and her children. She started her business before the death of her husband. 

She is hoping for a loan of N60,000 to purchase more materials to make more cellophane to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to produce more cellophane

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol. She is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. Lina is 35 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar and resturant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more brewing ingredients

loans.name: Harrietta

texts.en:
Harrietta is 40 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home.

Harrietta is a LAPO client who sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She is a hardworking woman and she sells for long hours to make more profits to meet the basic needs of her family.

Harrietta is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Gnaling

texts.fr: Gnaling G. est une femme de 37 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants qui fréquentent tous l'école. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de ESCALE depuis le 19 décembre 2001. Son prêt lui permet d'acheter de la matière première et des ingrédients pour préparer elle même ses jus de fruits qu'elle revend dans le quartier. Les bénéfices qu'elle produit lui permettent d'aider son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille et la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Gnaling G. is a 37-year-old woman who is married and the mother of six children who all attend school. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de ESCALE since December 19, 2001. Her loan enables her to buy raw materials and ingredients for making fruit juices herself. She sells the juices in the district. The profits she makes allow her to help her husband to cover family expenses and provide schooling for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To advance her business selling fruit juices

loans.name: Balikudembe Group Of Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Rehema, 32, is a married lady with six children in Senior 2, Primary 7, Primary 4, Primary 3, Primary 3 and Infant school. She also helps to take care of two dependents: an orphan and her mother.

Rehema is a coffee seller plus she has had a retail shop in Buwoola for five years. She is able to make 80,000/= as profits each week. She says that she has been successful because of the good relationship she has with her clients plus the help of the loans. She works so hard to ensure that she educates her children to the highest level as well as to expand her business further.

Rehema needs a loan to help grow her business further by increasing her capital. In future, she would like to buy a plot of land and build a house for her children.

loans.use: To recapitalise her business with more products

loans.name: Victoire Ablawa

texts.fr: V. Victoire Ablawa est née en 1964 et réside depuis sa naissance au quartier Tonato à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une veuve ayant deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et encore à sa charge. Seule Victoire Ablawa assure les dépenses de sa famille. Victoire Ablawa a arrêté l'école au cours primaire. Depuis près de trente ans, Victoire Ablawa mène comme activité la vente d'huile végétale, de biscuits, de bombons et d'oeufs. Victoire Ablawa mène également comme activité secondaire, la vente de cartes de recharge téléphonique. Victoire Ablawa a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Dans le but de diversifier son activité par la vente d'autres produits et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Victoire Ablawa sollicite un autre crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
V. Victoire Ablawa was born in 1964 and has been residing since birth in the Tonato district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a widow with two children who are both in school and still in her care. She is the only one ensuring that family expenses are being met. Victoire Ablawa dropped out of primary school. For almost 30 years, she has been running a business selling vegetable oil, cookies, candy, and eggs. She also runs a secondary business selling mobile phone recharge cards. She has had ALIDé loans before, which she has repaid. With the goal of diversifying her business by selling other goods, and to satisfy more customers, she’s requesting another ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of cookies, trays of eggs, phone recharge cards, and sacks of rice

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Enogie

texts.en:
Enogie sells soup ingredients like cray fish, dry pepper, melon seeds at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to expand this business in the future. She is a focused, hard worker and she hopes to excel in her business and family life. She is 60 years old and she is a widow with five children. She takes care of her children alone. She sells long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed her children.

Enogie is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more soup ingredients to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha Kibayasi S. is a Tanzanian businesswoman who is married and has five children. She runs a charcoal business at Yombo Buza in Dar es Salaam and has been in the business for four years. She purchases her business goods directly from the wholesale suppliers and then sells them to her customers.

Asha is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia J. is currently in the business of selling bread and tea at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more sugar to make more tea to sell. Lucia is 35 years old and is married to a businessman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more sugar to make more tea to sell

loans.name: Yaxenia Magali

texts.en:
Yaxenia Magali G. C. lives with her husband and 4 year old son in the Paraiso district of Guayaquil.  While her husband works as a guard for a local bank, Ms. G. sells rice to neighbors out of her home.  Every 22 days, Mr. G. drives approximately 2.5 hours to Marabi in order to buy 15 sacks of rice for his wife to sell.  They are able to buy each sack of rice for 21 dollars and sell the rice in smaller increments for a total of 40 dollars per sack. 

Ms. G. is requesting a loan in order to buy more sacks of rice. This will allow her family to buy a greater quantity of sacks at a lower rate per sack.  In the future, she hopes that profits from rice sales will allow her to fix the rooms of her house.  Ms.G. is thankful for any support you may be able to provide her business so that her family may prosper.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk for resale

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena is 32 years old, married, and has one child. Her child attends a private school. Her husband is a printer. She has a computer center where she sells computer services, computer accessories, and stationery. She hopes to expand her business by owning a computer school in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more computer accessories and stationery to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more computer accessories and stationery

loans.name: Rucia

texts.en:
Rucia K. is a Tanzanian businesswoman.  She is married and has two children in primary school. She runs a cosmetics shop in the Buguruni district of Dar es Salaam. She purchases goods from the wholesale stores at Kariakoo city shopping center and then resells them in Buguruni at retail. 

She has been in this business for five years and uses her business income to pay the children's school fees and meet the family's daily needs. She needs a loan of 600,000 Tanzanian shillings to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Edosa

texts.en:
Edosa is 43 years old and married with 5 children. Her husband is a government worker. She is excited to take her Kiva loan.

She will use this loan to invest in her business selling groceries, drinks and foodstuffs at retail prices. She is a hard working woman and she is determined to excel in her business and family life. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her 5 children.

She hopes for a loan amount N70,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Diénaba

texts.fr: Diénabou B. est une femme de 47 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BAMET DIATTACOUNDA depuis le 18 décembre 2001. Son prêt lui permet de développer un petit commerce de lait, elle achète son produit en grande quantité et revend au détail dans son quartier. ses bénéfices lui offrent la possibilité de participer à la prise ne charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Diénabou B. is a 47-year-old married woman and a mother of six. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of BAMET DIATTACOUNDA since December 18, 2001. Her loan enables her to develop a small milk business, where she buys her product in bulk and sells it retail in her neighborhood. Her earnings give her the ability to take care of her family.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her milk business

loans.name: Syprose Achieng

texts.en:
Syprose O., 35, is a married shopkeeper with three children.

In her shop, which she has run for seven years, she sells household food and products such as sugar, rice flour, cooking fats, baking flour, soda mild and detergents.

She runs the operation by herself and the store is located by the side of a main road. It is a busy location, but she does face significant competition. In the future, she hopes to establish another branch of her business and become the most established shop in the area.

Syprose describes herself as hardworking and patient.

loans.use: Additional stock for store, e.g., rice, sugar, milk

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en: Tatu K. is a Tanzanian businesswoman. She has two businesses: one selling timber and the other selling charcoal. She is married and has seven children. One child is in primary school but the rest are running their own businesses. She buys timber and charcoal wholesale and then sells it at her shops in Buguruni district, Dar es Salaam. She has been in business for 10 years and her income has enabled her to build a residential house and pay her children's school fees. She is requesting a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to ramp up her business.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Camille

texts.fr: H. Camille est né le 19 Juillet 1965 et réside depuis une douzaine d'année au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Camille est marié à ADJAÏ Anne-Marie, une ménagère. Le couple à trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Seul Camille assure les charges de la famille. Camille a arrêté les classes au secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Camille exerce depuis une vingtaine d'année le métier de calligraphie dans son quartier. En plus de cela, Camille mène comme activité secondaire, la teinte d'habits. Camille achète ses articles à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est un ancien client de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Pour renforcer davantage son activité, Camille sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Camille ambitionne créer un établissement de calligraphie.
texts.en:
Camille H. was born on July 19, 1965. For a dozen years, he's been living in the Agla neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Camille is married to Anne-Marie ADJAÏ, a housewife. They have three school-attending children they have to support. Camille provides for the family alone. He dropped out of secondary school. To provide for himself and for his family, Camille has been a calligrapher in his neighborhood for about twenty years. In addition, he has a secondary business, dying clothes. He buys his supplies in Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin. He's already a client from Kiva's partner, Alidé, and has already benefited from two loans, which were repaid without problems. In order to further bolster his business, Camille is seeking a third loan from Alidé. He ambitions to open a calligraphy shop.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dyes and fabrics

loans.name: Jaguru

texts.en:
Jaguru J. is currently in the business of selling various items at the shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar, salt, etc. to sell.

Jaguru is 36 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has 5 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar, salt, etc. to sell

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es:
El socio RICARDO pertenece al banco comunal “MINIBANK”, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

El socio tiene 68 años de edad, es viudo, tiene 4 hijos profesionales y es jubilado.

El tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de “jora o maíz fermentado” para las picanterías del Cusco. Las dueñas de las picanterías preparan la chicha de jora, comidas, etc. La chicha de jora es una bebida ancestral en el Perú y América.   
    
El socio requiere el préstamo para aumentar la producción de más jora comprando más maíz para hacer fermentar.

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
This member-partner, Richard, belongs to the communal bank “MINIBANK”. He is a native of the city of Cusco. He is a 68 year old retiree, a widower, and has 4 children who are professionals. He has a small business selling “jora”, or fermented corn to the authentic restaurants in Cusco that sell “la chicha de jora” and regional dishes. La Chicha de Jora is an ancestral drink in Peru and Latin America. He requires a loan to increase his production of jora by buying more corn to ferment. He is grateful for the opportunity afforded to him in this way and he commits to complying with the payment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase capital for the sale of jora

loans.name: Lilia Dolores

texts.en:
Lilia Dolores C. P. lives with her husband in the Paraiso district of Guayaquil and has four older children. They live in a very fragile home made of wood and cane. Ms. C. and her husband have a chicken coop in their backyard to sell chickens, but she wants to branch out into encebollado production and sales. Encebollado is a very popular Ecuadorian dish; it is a soup-like dish made of fish, yuca, rice, tomatoes and onions and generally sprinkled with lemon/lime juice.

Ms. C. began making encebollado with her sister and is currently selling from her home for $1.50 each dish. She sells approximately $35 worth daily (even more on weekends). She wakes up at 3 am in order to have her encebollado stock ready by 7 am. She is requesting a loan to buy ingredients and supplies for encebollado – especially yuca, fish and rice. In the future, Ms. C. hopes to fix her home and have a proper store.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for "encebollado"

loans.name: Vera

texts.en: Vera is married with one child. She runs a small business selling perfumes, cosmetics, etc. Vera received this business from her parents. During the five years that she has been in it, Vera has been able to develop the business and increase the number of clients as well as monthly sales. Vera's business goal is to grow the business further. She has already used microloans and found them very helpful. This time Vera would like to borrow 15,000 hryvnia to purchase more inventory. Vera will use the additional income to fix the house she lives in with her husband and son.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Wambui Waithaka

texts.en:
Wambui is 55 years old and operates a clothing sales business. She buys clothing in Nairobi on Fridays and Saturdays: bras, underwear, tops, skirts and hair pieces. On Sundays she takes a bus to Tanzania, arriving mid-day on Monday. She takes her merchandise to retail shops and sells it. She rests for two days as she waits for payment, and then on Wednesday takes a bus back to Nairobi, arriving mid-day on Thursday. She has repeated this schedule every week for the last 15 years. From her business, Wambui generates profits of about 20,00 Kenyan shillings a month.

Wambui has never borrowed from another MFI, but has taken part in a merry-go-round system in which neighbors pooled funds together every week and took turns at who got the pool. Wambui will use this loan to purchase clothing (women's merchandise) to sell during her weekly sales trips to Tanzania.

Wambui dreams of owning her own house that has water and electricity. She describes herself as hardworking and enjoys gardening when she is not traveling.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To buy clothing (primarily women's merchandise) to sell to retailers in Tanzania

loans.name: Peter Karigi

texts.en:
Peter is 39 years old and runs a motorcycle taxi business in the town of Tinganga, outside of Kiambu. He has been operating this business for the past year and a half and generates a daily income of about 800 Kenyan shillings (KES). Peter's customers are primarily men he transports to the farms where they work or carries their wares to sell in the market.

Peter plans to use this loan to buy a new motorcycle to expand his business into running two taxis. He has saved 20,000 KES to pay the difference between this loan and the cost of the motorcycle (80,000 KES). He will hire someone in the area to drive his current motorcycle taxi and he will drive the new one. Peter plans to use the extra profit he earns to purchase dairy cows so that his income is more stable. He describes himself as hardworking.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Salimatou

texts.fr: A. Salimatou est née le 04 Octobre 1955 et vit depuis une vingtaine d'année à Zogbohouè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Salimatou est mariée à SEWAVI Benjamin, et est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés, dont un est à sa charge. Salimatou vit seule avec son enfant et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Salimatou n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Salimatou vend depuis trente ans, du charbon de bois et des plastiques à son domicile. Salimatou s'approvisionne au Nord du Bénin et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Pour accroître le volume de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Salimatou sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Salimatou A. was born on October 4, 1955. For about twenty years, she's been living in Zogbohouè, Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Salimatou is married to Benjamin SEWAVI, and the mother of two school-attending children. She has to support one of her children. She lives alone with him, and has to support the family on her own. Salimatou never attended school. To provide for herself, she's been selling charcoal and plasticware at her house for thirty years. She gets her supplies in Northern Benin, and also in Dantokpa, an international marketplace in Benin. She's already a client of Kiva's partner, Alidé, and she already benefited from two loans, which were repaid without problems. In order to expand her business to better meet customer demand, Salimatou is seeking a third loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Tirus Murage

texts.en:
Tirus is 44 years old and married with five children. His main source of income is from a portrait (wall-hanging) sales business, which he has been operating for eight years. Tirus used to hawk a variety of items (pegs, basins, mirrors, portraits, etc.) and discovered that portraits sold the best. From this knowledge, he decided to operate exclusively in the sale of portraits. He now earns a profit of about 10,000 Kenyan shillings a month from this.

With this loan from KADET, a Kiva partner, Tirus is expanding his source of income. He is opening a small general shop to sell items like soap, gum, maize, rice, salt, candy, bread, soda, cooking fat and eggs. The location of this shop is on the Kiambu-Ndumberi highway and his customers are neighbors in the area. 

Tirus' dream is to educate his children through the high school level and to continue to grow his business. 

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To open a small general shop as a secondary business to sell items like soap, gum, rice, maize, salt, bread, etc.

loans.name: Luz María

texts.es:
Luz María tiene 35 años de edad, su esposo la abandonó hace dos años y desde entonces vive junto a su madre y a sus cuatro hijos en el distrito de Cayaltí, ubicado a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace seis meses se dedica por las tardes a la venta de papas rellenas, tortitas de choclo y salchipapas (platos típicos de la región) que ella misma prepara y los ofrece en u pequeño establecimiento improvisado cerca de su casa. Su producto goza de mucha acogida debido a su buena sazón y a la higiene con la que los prepara.

Su clientela ha venido aumentando y el poco capital con el que trabaja no es suficiente para cubrir esta demanda, por lo que se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 400 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de insumos para elaboración de alimentos.

Luz María es una mujer trabajadora y que ha luchado por sacar adelante a su familia a pesar de las adversidades. Su sueño es instalar una bodega con la cual pueda seguir apoyando a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Luz Maria is 35 years old. Since her husband left 2 years ago she has been living with her 4 children and her mother in the district of Cayalti, located an hour from the city of Chiclayo. For the last 6 months she has worked in the afternoons selling papas rellenas, tortitas de choclo, and salchipapas (regional dishes) that she prepares herself and offers for sale in a small, improvised establishment near her home. Her products have a great reception due to good seasoning and the hygiene with which they are prepared. Her clientele has increased and the little working capital she has is not sufficient to cover the demand. For this reason, she has seen the need to ask for a loan, for the first time, from Edpyme Alternativa of 400 PEN (Peruvian Nuevo Soles). She plans to invest the loan in the production of food. Luz Maria is a hard working woman and has struggled to support her family in spite of her adversities. She dreams of opening a store to better support her children.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of inputs for food processing

loans.name: Florencia

texts.es:
La socia FLORENCIA pertenece al banco comunal “MINIBANK”, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

La socia tiene 58 años de edad, es casada, tiene 2 hijos un varón y una mujer.

La socia tiene un pequeño restaurante (picantería) de venta de comida y bebidas. La socia prepara la bebida tradicional del Cusco como es la chicha de jora y entre las comidas que sirve tiene el tradicional pipían de cuy, habasucho, etc. La chicha de jora es una bebida ancestral en el Perú y América.       

La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar la venta de comida comprando más víveres como arroz, azúcar, aceite, etc., para la preparación de más platos típicos de la región.   
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
The member-partner, Florencia, belongs to the communal bank “MINIBANK”. She is a native of the city of Cusco. She is 58 years old, is married, has 2 children, a boy and a girl. She has a small restaurant that sells regional food and beverages. She prepares a traditional beverage of Cusco called “la chicha de jora”. Among the dishes that she serves are the traditional "pipian de cuy", "habasucho," etc. She requires a loan to increase sales by buying more basic supplies such as rice, sugar, oil, etc., to prepare the ethnic food of the area. She is grateful for the opportunity provided and promises to comply with the payment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase capital to for the sale of food.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariama C. est une femme de 29 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Kounkané3 depuis le 19 juin 2003 et y a bénéficié  de 12 prêts qu'elle a toujours remboursés. Elle fait de la transformation et vente de pâte d'arachide. Ses bénéfices lui permettent d'aider son mari pour la prise en charge quotidienne de la famille.
texts.en:
Mariama C. is a 29 year old married woman, mother of five children. She has been a member of the Village Bank of Kounkané 3 since June 19, 2003. She has received 12 loans that she has always paid back.

She transforms and sells peanut butter. Her profit allows her to help her husband with the daily household expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To promote her retail business

loans.name: Aminatou

texts.fr: B. Aminatou est née le 04 Octobre 1955. Mariée à BOUCARI Djibrill, un agent retraité de la Société Béninoise de Brasserie, Aminatou est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés, dont un est à sa charge. Aminatou vit seule avec ses enfants au quartier Zogbohouè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis cinq ans. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par Aminatou seule. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Aminatou mène comme activité depuis une trentaine d'année, la vente d'encens, de parfums, pommades et d'articles religieux (chapelets, livrets de prières, etc.). C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Aminatou désire accroître son capital et créer plus tard sa propre boutique pour la vente de ses produits. C'est pourquoi Aminatou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Aminatou B. was born on October 4, 1955. She is married to Djibrill BOUCARI, a retired employee of the Benin Society of Brewery. Aminatou is the mother of two children, both in school, and she supports one of them. For the last five years, Aminatou has lived alone with her children in the neighborhood of Zogbohouè in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Aminatou is the sole provider for the family's expenses.

Aminatou never attended school, for the last thirty years she has been selling incense, perfumes, ointments and religious items (rosaries, prayer books, etc…). She is a long time member of ALIDé, having already obtained two loans that were paid back in full. Aminatou would like to increase her capital, and later on she would like to develop her own store to retail her products. For this reason Aminatou is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of incense, religious items, perfumes and ointments.

loans.name: Jhonatan

texts.es:
Jhonatan, trabaja en una empresa distribuidora de perfumes y es independiente. Vive con sus padres en la zona de Pampahasi de la Ciudad de La Paz.
El crédito será destinado para la compra de perfumes  y distribuir en forma independiente sus productos y mejorar sus ingresos y calidad de vida.
Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, las ganas de superarse le dan la oportunidad de obtener este crédito.
texts.en:
Jhonatan works in a company that distributes perfumes and where he works independently. He lives with his parents in the area of Pampahasi in the city of La Paz. The loan requested will be used for the purchase of perfumes that he will distribute independently to improve his earnings and quality of life. This is the first time he is asking for a loan with IMPRO as he is eager to better himself through it.

Translated from Spanish by Rocio Vargas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of perfumes for sale

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca es una madre de familia de 60 años de edad, madre de siete hijos, actualmente vive sólo con su esposo en el distrito de Zaña, ubicado a 50 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Hace dos años retomó sus actividades de costurera debido a que la pensión de jubilado de su esposo no era suficiente para el mantenimiento de su hogar. La calidad y responsabilidad con la que realiza su trabajo ha hecho que su negocio sea muy solicitado por sus clientes.

Debido al constante uso su máquina de coser de pedal ha sufrido algunos desperfectos mecánicos que necesitan de urgente reparación para que ella siga trabajando; por este motivo está solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

Francisca es una mujer muy carismática que ofrece un buen trato a todas las personas que la visitan. Su más grande anhelo es comprar una máquina de coser eléctrica con la que pueda seguir realizando su trabajo.
texts.en:
Francisca is 60 year-old mother of seven children, although currently she lives only with her husband in the Zaña district, located 50 minutes away from the city of Chiclayo. Two years ago Francisca began working again as a seamstress, due to the fact that her husband's retirement pension was not enough to pay for the household costs. The quality and responsibility with which she runs her business has made it very popular with customers. Due to its constant use, the pedal on her sewing machine has been damaged and needs urgent repairing for Francisca to continue working. For this reason she is asking for the first time Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 500 nuevos soles. Francisca is a very charismatic woman that treats everyone who visits her well. Her greatest wish is to buy an electric sewing machine, that she could continue to work on.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair of a sewing machine pedal.

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: D. Odette est née le 03 Septembre 1954 et est marié à AHEHEHINNOU Christian, un entrepreneur. Le couple a sept enfants tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à leur charge. Odette réside au quartier Vodjè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis cinq ans. Odette supporte seule les charges de la famille.  Ayant arrêté très tôt les classes, Odette s'est mise depuis près de 20 ans à vendre divers articles (pâtes alimentaires, conserves, savons, dentifrices, lait, défrisants, biscuits, mayonnaise, papier hygiénique, etc.)à son domicile. Odette mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de cartes de recharges téléphoniques. Odette achète ces divers articles à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Odette est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà obtenu quatre crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Afin d'agrandir davantage son activité et de faire face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Odette sollicite un cinquième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Odette is born September 03, 1954 and married to AHEHEHINOU Christian, a businessman. The couple has seven children, all in school, two of whom they take care of. Odette has been living in the neighborhood of Vodje in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin for five years. Odette alone bears the family expenses. Having stopped school early, Odette started selling various items for about 20 years( pasta, canned goods, soap,toothpaste, milk, straighteners, biscuits,mayonnaise, toilet paper,etc) in her home. Odette also sells rechargeable telephone cards as a side business. She buys these micelleneous products at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Odette is an old customer of ALIDe, having already obtained four loans from ALIDe, all repaid correctly. In order to expand her business more and to meet the growing needs of her clientele, Odette is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetic products, rechargeable telephone cards, canned goods, soap, pasta.

loans.name: Usioma

texts.en:
Usioma is 35 years old and married with three children. She sells groceries, juice and drinks to make a living in the Delta state of Nigeria. She sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed her immediate family members. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits. She hopes to combine her business with her tailoring skills in the future. 

She hopes for a loan amount of 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Margort

texts.es:
La socia MARGORT pertenece al banco comunal “MINIBANK”, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

La socia tiene 31 años de edad, es casada, ella esta embarazada va tener su primer hijo. Ella es profesora del nivel secundaria del colegio “San Juan Bautista de Coya”, Coya se encuentra en la ciudad de pisaq a 1 hora de la ciudad imperial del Cusco.

Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con la atención de su pequeño negocio de venta de material de arreglo de interiores como yeso, cemento, etc. 

La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar la venta de materiales de decoración de interiores.    
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Margort is a member of the communal bank "Minibank," and is a native of the city of Cusco. Margort is 31 years-old, married, and is pregnant with her first child. She is a high school level teacher at "San Juan Bautista de Coya" school. Coya is located in Pisaq, about one hour away from the imperial city, Cusco. Besides taking care of the household, Margort has a small business selling material for interior repairs, such as plaster, cement, etc. This member needs this loan to increase her sales of interior decoration materials. Margort is grateful for the opportunity offered through the institution and at the same time promises to make the payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to increase sales of construction materials.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with no children yet. She sells various types of women's clothing. Her kiosk is located at the food market. This location allows Irina to offer her goods to many people who come to the market to get food. Irina started her business five years ago. Her mother, who had a lot of sales experience, helped Irina to make this business a success.

Irina would like to borrow 15,000 Ukrainian grivna to increase her assortment of inventory. She would like to develop her business further and start a second location.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of inventory

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience sells various brands of detergent at retail prices to her customers. She is 40 years old and married with two children. Her older child studies at the College of Education while the younger one is in secondary school. Patience's husband is a commercial driver. She lives in Ughelli, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more detergent to sell. In the future, she hopes to purchase a van that she will use to distribute her detergent. She hopes to be the sole distributor of detergent in her community. 
Patience is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase detergent to sell

loans.name: Diarraye

texts.fr: Diarraye S. est une femme de 36 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants, elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Kounkané3 depuis le 13 janvier 2006. Elle fait de la transformation et vente de pâte d'arachide. Elle soutien son mari avec les bénéfices qu'elle réalise de son commerce.
texts.en:
Diarraye S. is a 36-year-old woman who is married and the mother of five children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de Kounkané3 since January 13, 2006. She processes and sells peanut butter. She supports her husband with the profits she earns from her commerce.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her small-scale peanut butter business

loans.name: Saré Mamady Group

texts.fr: Nous venons pour la première fois solliciter auprès des bailleurs de Kiva qui va nous permettre de développer des activités de commerce d'appoint dans notre écovillage.Nous sommes dans une zone très fréquentée par les population qui transitent chez nous pour attendre un moyen de transport afin de pouvoir aller ailleurs. C'est pour cela que nous venons solliciter ce prêt pour pouvoir créer un stock de denrées de premières nécessités, afin de soulager ces populations qui habitent les villages environnants, quand à la disponibilité de marchandises dont ils ont besoin et qui leur fait se déplacer très loin de leur habitation. Nous allons donc ouvrir une petite boutique qui contiendrait tous les articles d'usage quotidien dans les maisons et le revendre aux villageois.
texts.en:
We’re here for the first time making a request of Kiva lenders that will enable us to develop additional commercial businesses in our eco-village. We are in an area very buS. with people who travel via our location, where they wait for a means of transport to go elsewhere. For this reason, we’ve come to request this loan, so as to be able to create a stock of essential goods. This is in order to bring relief to these people who live in the surrounding villages, since the availability of the goods they need makes them travel very far from their homes. We are therefore going to open a small store, which will contain all the day-to-day goods for household use, and we will resell these goods to the villagers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy commonly used family consumer products

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 29-year-old Alice S. from Mbozi. She is single with three children between the ages of 6 and 14. Alice has been running a business purchasing and selling crops and clothes since 2006. She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week. Alice currently earns about $100 from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to improve the quality and range of products she offers. Alice thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for her business

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret sells cooked foods and drinks to make a living in her community in Ughelli, Delta state. She sells for long hours to ensure that she is able to assist her husband to meet the basic needs of the family. She is 35 years old and married with six children. Her eldest child is 17 years old while the youngest child is 1 year old. Her husband is a government worker. 

She hopes for the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks
